editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TOWN-FOPP: OR Sir Timothy Tawdrey. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at his Royal Highness the DUKE's THEATRE.
LONDON, Printed by T. N. for Iames Magnes and Rich. Bentley in Russel-street in Covent-garden near the Piazza's. M.DC.LXXVII.

list.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
list.item: Bellmour Nephew to the Lord Plotwell, Contracted to Celinda.
Friendlove Brother to Celinda, in Love with Diana.

Sir Timothy Tawdrey A Fopp Knight, design'd to Marry Celinda.
Hangers on to Sir Timothy.
Sham
Sharp
Trusty An old Steward to Bellmour's Family.
The Lady Diana Neece to the Lord Plotwell.
Celinda Sister to Friendlove, Contracted to Bellmour.
Betty Flauntit kept by Sir Timothy.

Driver A Bawd.
Two Whores.
Ienny
Doll

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: AS Countrey Squire who yet had never known
The long expected joy of being in Town;
Whose careful Parents scarce permitted Heir
To Ride from Home unless to Neighbouring Fair:
At last by happy Chance is hither led
To purchase Clap with loss of Maidenhead;
Turns wond'rous Gay, bedizen'd to Excess,
Till he is all Burlesque in Mode and Dress:
Learns to talk loud in Pit, grows Wily too,
That is to say, makes mighty Noise, and Show.
So a young Poet who had never been
Dabling beyond the height of Ballading;
Who, in his brisk Essayes, durst ne're excel
The lucky flight of Rhiming Dogerel,
Sets up with this sufficient Stock, on Stage,
And has, perchance, the luck to please the Age:
He draws you in, like cozening Citizen,
Cares not how bad the Ware, so Shop be fine.
As tawdry Gown and Petticoat gain more
(Tho' on a dull diseas'd ill-favor'd Whore)
Than prettier Frugal, tho' on Holy-day,
When every City Spark has leave to Play,
—Damn Her she must be Sound She is so Gay.
So let the Scenes be fine, you'll ne're inquire
For Sence, but lofty flights in nimble Wire.
—What we Present to Day is none of these;
But we cou'd wish it were, for we wou'd please,
And that you'll swear we hardly meant to do:
Yet here's no Sence; Pox on't, but here's no Show;
But a plain Story, that will give a taste
Of what your Grandsires lov'd i'th' Age that's past.

div.head: THE TOWN-FOPP: OR Sir TIMOTHY TAWDREY.
Scene 1. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy Tawdrey, Sham and Sharpe.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: HEreabouts is the House wherein dwells, the Mistriss of my heart; For she has money Boyes, mind me, money in abundance, or she were not for me—the Wench her self is good natur'd, and inclin'd to be civil, but a Pox on't—She has a Brother a conceited Fellow, whom the world mistakes for a fine Gentleman, for he has Travell'd, talks Languages, bows with a bone meine, and the rest, but by fortune he shall entertain you with nothing but words—

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Nothing else?—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No—He's no Countrey Squire Gentlemen, will not Game, Whore, nay, in my Conscience you will hardly get your selves Drunk in his Company—He Treats A-la-mode, half Wine, half Water, and the rest—But to the business, this Fellow loves his Sister dearly, and will not trust her in this lewd Town, as he calls it, without him, and hither he has brought her to marry me.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: A Pox upon him for his pains—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: So say I—But my comfort is, I shall be as weary of her, as the best Husband of 'em all—But there's conveniency in it; besides, the match being as good as made up by the old Folks in the Countrey, I must submit—The Wench I never saw yet, but they say she's handsom— But no matter for that, there's Money, my Boyes!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well Sir, we will follow you—but as dolefully as people do their Friends to the Grave, from whence they're never to return, at least not the same substance, the thin aiery Vision of a brave Good Fellow, we may see thee hereafter, but that's the most.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Your pardon, sweet Sharp, my whole design in it is to be Master of my self, and with part of her Portion to set up my Miss, Betty Flauntit, which, by the way, is the main end of my • arrying, the rest you'll have your shares of—Now I am forc • d to take you up Suits at treble Prizes, have damn'd Wine and Meat put upon us, 'cause the Reckoning is to be Book'd: But ready Money ye Rogues! What Charms it has! Makes the Waiters flie Boyes, and the • aster with Cap in hand— excuse what's amiss, Gentlemen—Your Worship shall command the best—and the rest—How briskly the Box and Dice dance, and the ready Money submits to the lucky Gamester, and the gay Wench consults with every Beauty to make her self agreeable to the Man with ready Money. In fine, dear Rogues! All things are sacrific'd to it's pow'r; and no Mortal conceives the joy of, Argent Content. 'Tis this pow'rful God that makes me submit to the Devil Matrimony; and then thou art assur'd of me, my stout Lads of brisk Debauch.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: And is it possible you can be ty'd up to a Wife? Whil'st here in London, and free, you have the whole World to range in, and like a wanton Heifer, eat of every Pasture.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why dost think I'll be confin'd to my own dull Enclosure? No, I had rather feed coarsly upon the boundless Common, perhaps two or three dayes I may be in Love, and remain constant, but that's the most.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: And in three Weeks, should you Wed a Cinthia, you'd be a Monster.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What, thou meanest a Cuckold, I warrant? God help thee▪ But a Monster is only so from its Rarity, and a Cuckold is no such • strange thing in our Age.
sp.l: But who comes here?
Bellmour! Ah my little dear Rogue! How dost thou!
—Ned Friendlove too! Dear Lad, how dost thou too?
Why welcome to Town i'faith, and I'm glad to see you both.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir Tim. Tawdrey!—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: The same, by fortune, dear Ned; And how, and how Man, how go matters?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Between who Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why any body Man: But, by fortune, I'm overjoy'd to meet thee: But where dost think I was going?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Is't possible one shou'd divine?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Is't possible you shou'd not, and meet me so near your Sisters Lodgings? Faith I was coming to pay my Respects and Services, and the rest—Thou know'st my meaning—The old business of the Silver World Ned; by Fortune it's a mad Age, we live in Ned, and here be so many—wicked Rogues, about this damn'd lewd Town, that 'Faith I am fain to speak, in the vulgar modish stile, in my own defence, and Rally Matrimony, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Matrimony!—I hope you are so exactly refin'd a Man of the Town, that you will not offer once to think of so dull a thing, let that alone for such cold complexions as Bellmour here, and I that have not attain'd to that most excellent faculty of keeping yet, as you, Sir Timothy, have done, much to your glory, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Who I Sir? You do me much Honour: I must confess I do not find the softer Sex cruel; I am received as well as another Man of my Parts.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Of your Money, you mean Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why Faith Ned, thou art i'th' right, I love to buy my pleasure, for, by Fortune, there's as much pleasure in Vanity and Variety, as any Sins I know; What think'st thou Ned?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I am not of your mind, I love to love upon the square; and that I may be sure not to be cheated with false Ware, I present 'em nothing but my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, and have the consolation, of seeing your frugal Huswifery Miss, sit in the Pit, at a Play, in a long Scarf, and Night-gown, for want of Points, and Garniture.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If she be clean, and pretty, and drest in Love, I can excuse the rest, and so will she.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
I vow to Fortune Ned, thou must come to London, and be a little manag'd: 'Slife Man, should'st thou talk so aloud in good Company, thou would'st be counted a strange Fellow, Pretty—and drest with Love—a fine Figure, by Fortune; No, Ned, the painted Chariot, gives a Lustre, to every ordinary Face, and makes a Woman, look like Quality; ay, so like, by Fortune, that you shall not know one from t'other, till some scandalous, out-of-favor'd-laid-aside-Fellow of the Town, cry— Damn her, for a Bitch—how scornfully the Whore regards me—She has forgot since Iack—such a one, and I, club'd for the keeping of her, when both our Stocks, well manag'd, wou'd not amount to above seve •
shillings six pence a week; besides now and then a Treat of a Breasto •
Mutton▪ from the next Cooks—Then the other laughs, and cryes— I—Rott her—And tells his Story too, and concludes with who ma • nages the Gilt now? Why Faith some dismal Coxcomb or other, yo •
may be sure, replies the first: But Ned, these are R • gues, and Rascals, th •
value no Mans Reputation, because they despise their own: But Faith 〈◊〉
have laid aside all these vanities, now I have thought of Matrimony; b ••
I desire my Reformation may be a secret, because, as you know for 〈◊〉
Man of my Address, and the rest—'Tis not altogether so Jantee.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir, I assure you, it shall be so great a Secret for me, that I will never ask you who the happy Woman is, that's chosen for this great work of your Conversion.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ask me!—No, you need not, because you know already.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Who I? I protest Sir Timothy—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No Swearing, dear Ned, for 'tis not such a Secret, but I will trust my Intimates; these are my Friends, Ned; pray know them— This Mr Sham and this—by fortune, a very honest Fellow [Bows to 'em.] Mr Sharp, and may be trusted with a bus'ness that concerns you as well as me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Me? What do you mean Sir Timothy?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why Sir, you know what I mean.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What, not that I am to marry your Sister Celinda?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O this unsufferable Sott!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: My Sister, Sir, is very nice.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That's all one, Sir, the old People have adjusted the matter, and they are the most proper 〈◊〉 a Negotiation of that kind, which saves us the trouble of a tedious Courtship.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: That the old People have agreed the matter, is more than I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why Lord Sir, will you persuade me to that? don't you know that your Father (according to the method in such cases, being certain of my Estate) came to me thus—Sir Timothy Tawdrey!—You are a young Gentleman, and a Knight, I knew your Father well, and my right worshipful Neighbor, our Estates lie together, therefore Sir, I have a desire to have a near Relation with you—At which, I interrupted him, and cry • d —Oh Lord Sir! I vow to Fortune, you do me the greatest Honour Sir, and the rest—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I can endure no more, he marry fair Celinda?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee let him alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: To which he answer'd—I have a good Fortune—Have but my Son Ned, and this Girl, call'd Celinda, whom I will make a Fortune, sutable to yours▪ your honoured Mother, the Lady Tawdrey, and I, have as good as concluded the match already. To which I (who, tho I say it, am well eno • gh bred for a Knight) answer'd the Civility thus— I vow to Fortune Sir—I did not swear, but cry'd—I protest Sir, Celinda, deserves—no, no, I lye again, 'twas merits—I, Celinda— merits a much better Husband than I.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You speak more truth than you are aware of.

Well, Sir, I'll bring you to my Sister, and if she likes you, as well as my
Father does, she's yours; otherwise, I have so much tenderness for her, as to leave her choice free.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Sir you Compliment. Alons, Entrons.

div.head: Scene 2. A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I wonder my Brother stayes so long; sure Mr Bellmour is not yet arriv'd, yet he sent us word he would be here to day. Lord how impatient I grow.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Ay, so methinks if I had the hopes of enjoying so sweet a Gentleman, as Mr Bellmour, I shou'd be so too—But I am past it— Well, I have had my pantings, and heavings, my impatience, and qualms, my heats, and my colds, and my I know not whats—But I thank my stars, I have done with all those Fooleries.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Fooleries!—
Is there any thing in life but Love?
Wou'dst thou prai • e Heaven for thy Being,
Without that grateful part of it?
For I confess I Love.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You need not, your sighs, and daily (nay, and nightly too) disorders, plainly enough betray the truth.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Thou speak'st as if it were a Sin;
But if it be so, you your self help'd to make me wicked.
For e're I saw Mr Bellmour, you spoke the kindest things of him,
And e're I saw him, I was quite undone.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Quite undone! Now God forbid it: What, for Loving?
You said but now there was no life without it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But since my Brother came from Italy,
And brought young Bellmour to our house,
How very little thou hadst said of him;
How much above thy praise, I found the Youth?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Very pretty! You are grown a notable Proficient in Love—
And you are resolv'd (if he please) to Marry him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Or I must dye.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I, but you know the Lord Plotwell, has the possession of all his Estate, and if he Marry without his liking, has power to take away all his Fortune, and then I think it were not so good Marrying him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not Marrying him! Oh canst thou think so poorly of me?
Yes, I wou'd Marry him, tho' our scanty Fortune,
Cou'd onely purchase us
A loanly Cottage, in some silent place,
All cover'd o • re with Thatch,
Defended from the outrages of storms
By leafless Trees, in Winter, and from heat,
With shades, which their kind Boughs wou • d bear anew,
Under whose Covert, wee'd feed, our gentle Flock;
That shou • d in gratitude repay us Food,
And mean and humble Cloathing.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Very fine!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There we wou • d practise such degrees of Love,
Such lasting, innocent, unheard of joyes,
As all the busie World should wonder at,
And ami • st all the • r Glories, find none such.

sp.speaker: N • r.
sp.p: Good lack! how prettily Love teaches his Scholars to prattle? —But hear ye, fair Mrs Celinda, you have forgot to what end and purpose you came to Town, not to Marry Mr Bellmour, as I take it—but Sir Timothy Tawdrey, that Spark of Men.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh name him not—Let me not in one moment
Descend from Heaven to Hell—
How came that wretched thing into thy Noddle?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Faith Mistriss I took pity of thee, I saw you so elevated with thoughts of Mr Bellmour, I found it necessary to take you down a degree lower.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Why did not Heaven make all Men like to Bellmour?
So strangely sweet and charming.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry come up you speak well for your self;
Oh intolerable loving Creature!
But here comes the utmost of your wishes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My Brother and Bellmour! with strange Men!

div.stage: Enter Friendlove, Bellmour, Sir Timothy, Sham, and Sharpe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sister, I've brought you here a Lover, this is the worthy person you have heard of, Sir Timothy Tawdrey.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, • aith Madam, I am Sir Timothy Tawdrey, at your service —Pray are not you Mrs Celinda D • esswell?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: The same, but cannot return your Compliment.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord, not return a Compliment, faith Ned thy Sister • s quite spoil'd, for want of Town Education; 'tis pity, for she • s Devilish pretty.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: She • s modest. Sir, before Company; therefore these G • ntlemen and I will withdraw into the next Room.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.p: Inhumane Brother, will you leave me alone with this Sott?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yes, and i • you would be rid of the trouble of him, be not coy, nor witty; two things • e hates.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! Must she be blown upon by that Fool?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Patience dear Frank, a little while.

div.stage: [Sir Timothy walks about the Room, expecting when Celinda should speak.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Oh dear Nurse, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I that ever help you at a dead Lift, will not fail you now.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What a Pox not a word?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Sure this Fellow believes I • ll begin.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not yet—sure she has spoke her last—

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: The Gentleman's good natur'd, and has took pity on you, and will not trouble you, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: —Hey day, here • s Wooing indeed—Will she never begin trow—This some would call an excellent quality in her Sex—But a Pox on • t I do not like it—Well, I see I must break silence at last— Madam—not answer me—shaw this is meer ill breeding—by Fortune —it can be nothing else—Oh my Conscience, if I should kiss her, she w • uld not bid me stand off—I'll try—

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you mistake your Mark.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: So I should, if I were to look in thy mouldy Chaps, good Matron—Can your Lady speak?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Try Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Why speak to her first.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I never knew a Woman want a Cue, for that, but all that I have met with, were still before-hand with me, in tittle tattle.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Likely those you have met with may, but this is no such Creature Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: I must confess, I am unus'd to this kind of Dialogue,
And I am an Ass, if I know what to say to such a Creature,
—But come, will you answer me to one Question?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I can Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: But first I should ask you if you can speak?
For that's a Question too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And if I cannot, how will you be answer'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Faith that's right; why then you must do't by signs.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: But grant I can speak, what is't you'll ask me?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Can you Love?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Oh yes, Sir, many things; I love my Meat, I love abundance of Adorers, I love choice of new Cloaths, new Playes, and like a right Woman, I love to have my Will.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Spoke like a well-bred person, by Fortune; I see there's hopes of thee Celinda; thou wilt in time learn to make a very fashionable Wife, having so much Beauty too. I see Attracts, and Allurements, wanton Eyes, the languishing turn of the Head, and all that invites to Temptation.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Would that please you in a Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Please me, why Madam, what do you take me to be? a Sott?—a Fool?—or a dull Italian, of the humor of your Brother? —No, no, I can assure you, she that Marries me, shall have Franchise—But my pretty Miss, you must learn to talk a little more.—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I have not Wit, and Sense enough, for that.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Wit! Oh la, O la, Wit! as if there were any Wit requir'd in a Woman when she talks; no, no matter for Wit, or Sense: talk but loud, and a great deal, to shew your white teeth, and smile, and be very confident, and 'tis enough.—Lord what a • ight 'tis to see a pretty Woman stand right up an end in the middle of a Room, playing with her Fan, for want of something to keep her in countenance. No, s • e that is mine, I will teach to entertain at another rate.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: How Sir? Why what do you take my young Mistriss to be?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A Woman—and a fine one, and so fine as she, ought to permit her self to be seen, and be ador • d.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Out upon you, would you expose your Wife; by my troth and I were she, I know what I wou'd do.—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Thou do—what thou wouldst have done sixty Years ago, thou meanest.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Marry come up, for a stinking Knight, worse than I have gone down with you, e're now—Sixty Years ago quoth ye—As old as I am—I live without Surgeons, wear my own Hair, am not in Debt to my Taylor, as thou art, and art fain to kiss his Wife, to persuade her Husband to be merciful to thee—who wakes thee every morning with his Clamour and long Bills, at thy Chamber door.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Prethee good Matron peace, I'll Compound with thee.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: 'Tis more than thou wilt do with thy Creditors, who, poor Souls, despair of a Groat in the Pound for all thou ow • st them, for Points, Lace, and Garniture—for all in fine, that makes thee a complete Fopp.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hold, hold, thy eternal Clack.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: And when none would trust thee farther, give Judgments for twice the Money tho • borrowest, and swear thy self at Age; and lastly, —to patch up your broken Fortune, you wou'd fain Marry my swe • t Mistriss Celinda here—But 'faith Sir, you're mistaken, her For • une shall not go to the maintenance of your Misses, which being once sure of, she, poor Soul, is sent down to the Coun • rey house, to learn Housewifery, and live without M • nkind, unless she can serve her s • lf with the handsom Steward, or so—whil'st you tear it away in Town, and live like Man and Wife with your Jilt, and are every day seen in the Glass Coach, whil'st your own natural Lady is hardly worth the hire of a Hack

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why thou damnabie confounded torment, wilt thou never cease?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, not till you raise your Siege, and be gone; go march to your Lady of Love, and debauch—go—You get no C • linda here.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: The Devil's in her tongue.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Good gentle Nurse, have mercy upon the poor Knight.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No more Mistriss, than he'll have on you, if Heaven had so abandon'd you, to put you into his power:—Mercy—quoth ye—no, no more than his Mistriss will have, when all his money's gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Will she never end?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Prethee forbear.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No more, than the Usurer would, to whom he has mortgag'd his best part of his Estate, would forbear a day after the promis'd payment of the money. Forbear—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not yet end: Can I Madam, give you a greater proof of my passion for you, than to endure this for your sake?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: This—thou art so sorry a creature, thou wilt endure any thing, for the lucre of her fortune; 'tis that thou hast a passion for: not that thou carest for money, but to sacrifice to thy lewdness, to purchase a Mistriss, to purchase the Reputation of as errant a Fool, as ever arriv'd at the honour of keeping, to purchase a little Grandeur, as you call it; that is, to make every one look at thee, and consider what a Fool thou art, who else might pass unreguarded amongst the common crowd.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: The Devil's in her tongue, and so 'tis in most Womens of her Age; for when 't has quitted the Tail, it repairs to her upper Tire.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Do not persuade me, Madam, I am resolv'd to make him weary of his Wooing.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
So God be prais'd, the storm is laid—And now Mrs. Celinda▪
give me leave to ask you, if it be with your leave, this affront is put
〈…〉 of my Quality?

sp.speaker: N • r.
sp.p: Thy Quality—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, I am a Gentleman, and a Knight.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Knight of the ill-favour'd Countenance is it?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: You are beholding to Don Quixot for that, and • tis so many Ages, since thou couldst see to read, I wonder thou hast not forgot all that ever belong • d to Books.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: My eye-sight • s good enough to see thee in all thy colours, thou Knight of the Burning Pestle thou.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Agen, that was out of a Play—heark ye Witch of Endor, hold your prating tongue, or I shall most well- • avourdly Cudgel ye.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: As your Friend the Hostess has it in a Play too, I take it, Ends which you pick up behind the Scenes, when you go to be laught at even by the Player Women.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Wilt thou have done, by Fortune I'll endure no more.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

div.stage: Enter Friendlove, Bellmour, Sham and Sharpe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Read here, the worst of News, that can arrive,
—What's the matter here?—Why how now Sir Timothy,
What up in Arms with the Women?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Ned, i • m glad thou • rt come—never was Tom Dove baited as I have been.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By whom? my Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, no, that old Mastiff there;—the young Whelp, came not on, thanks be prais'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How, her Father here to morrow, and here he sayes, that shall be the last moment, he will defer the Marriage of Celinda, to this Sott— Oh God, I shall grow mad, and so undo 'em all—I'll kill the Villain at the Altar—By my lost hopes I will—And yet there is some left—Could I but—speak to her—I must relie on Dresswells friendship—Oh God to morrow—Can I endure that thought—Can I endure to see the Traytor there, who must to morrow rob me of my Heaven—I'll own my flame—and boldly tell this Fopp, she must be mine—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir Timothy, I am sorry, and will chastise her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay Sir, I that am a Knight—a Man of Parts and Wit, and one that is to be your Brother, and design'd to be the glory of marrying Celinda.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I can endure no more—How Sir—You marry fair Celinda!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay Frank, Ay—Is she not a pretty little plump white Rogue, hah—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh I had forgot, thou art a modest Rogue, and to thy eternal shame, hadst never the Reputation of a Mistri • s—Lord, Lord, that I could see thee address thy self to a Lady—I fancy thee a very ridiculous Figure, in that posture, by Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why Sir—I can Court a Lady—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
Bell.
sp.p: Neither Sir—I can Love—and tell it too—and that you may believe me—look on this Lady Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Loo • on this Lady Sir—Ha, ha, ha,—Well Sir— Well Sir—And what then—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay view her well Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Pleasant this—Well Frank I do—And what then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is she not charming Fair—Fair to a wonder!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well Sir, 'tis granted—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And canst thou think this Beauty meant for thee, for thee dull common Man?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Very well, what will he say next?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I say, let me no more see thee approach this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How Sir, how?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not speak to her, not look on her—by Heaven—not think of her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How Frank, art in earnest?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Try, if thou dar'st?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not think of her—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No not so much as in a Dream, could I Divine it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Is he in earnest Mr Friendlove?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I doubt so Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What does he then pretend to your Sister?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, and no Man else, shall dare do so.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Take notice I am aff • onted in your Lodgings—for you Bellmour—You take me for an Ass—therefore meet me to morrow morning about 5, with your Sword in your hand, behind Southamp • on House.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis well—there we'll dispute our Title to Celinda.
Dull Animal! Ye Gods cou'd ne're Decree
So bright a Maid shou'd be possest by thee.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: WEll, 'tis an endless trouble, to have the Tuition of a Maid in Love, here is such Wishing and Longing—And yet one must force them to what they most desire, before they will admit of it— Here am I sent out a Scout of the Forlorn Hope, to discover the approach of the Enemy—Well—Mr. Bellmour, you are not to know, 'tis with the consent of Celinda, that you come—I must bear all the blame, what mischief soever comes of these Night-works.
Oh are you come—Your hour was Twelve, and • ow 'tis almost Two.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I could not get from Friendlove—Thou hast not told Celinda of my coming.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, no, ee'n make peace for me, and your self too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I warrant thee Nurse—Oh how I hope and fear this nights success!

div.head: Scene a Chamber, Celinda in her Night A • tire, leaning on a Table.
div.stage: Enter to her Bellmour and Nurse.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! Mr. Bellmour at this late hour in my Chamber!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes, Madam; but will approach no nearer till you permit me;
And sure you know my Soul too well to fear.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I do Sir, and you may approach yet nearer,
And let me know your business.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Love is my bus'ness, that of all the world
Only my flame as much surmounts the rest
As is the Objects beauty, I adore.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If this be all, to tell me of your Love,
To morrow might have done as well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh no, to morrow would have been too late,
Too late to make returns to all my pain.
—What disagreeing thing offends your Eyes?
I've no deformity about my Person,
I'm Young, and have a Fortune great as any
That do pretend to serve you;
And yet I find my interest in your heart,
Below those happy ones that are my Rivals.
Nay, every Fool that can but plead his Title,
And the poor interest that a Parent gives him,
Can merit more than I.
—What else my lovely Maid can give a freedom
To that same talking, idle Knighted Fopp.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh if I am so wretched to be his,
Surely I cannot live,
For, Sir, I must confess I cannot love him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But thou may'st do as bad, and marry him,
And that's a sin, I cannot over live
—No, hear my Vows—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But are you • ir in earnest?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: In earnest? Yes, by all that's good I am;
I Love you more than I do Life, or Heav'n •

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh what a pleasure 'tis to hear him say so!
—But pray, how long Sir, have you Lov'd me so?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: From the first moment that I saw your Eyes,
Your charming killing Eyes, I did adore 'em,
And ever since have languisht day and night.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Come, come, ne're stand asking of questions,
But follow your inclinations, and take him at his word.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Celinda, take her counsel,
Perhaps this is the last opportunity;
Nay, and by Heaven the last of all my Life,
If you refuse me now—
Say, will you never marry Man but me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray give me till to morrow, Sir, to answer you;
For I have yet some fears about my Soul
That take away my rest.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: To morrow! You must then marry—oh fatal word!
Another! a Beast, a Fool, tha • knows not how to value you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is't possible my Fate shou'd be so near?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Nay then dispose of your self, I say, and leave dissembling, 'tis high time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: This night the Letter came, the dreadful News
Of thy being married, and to morrow too.
Oh answer me, or I shall die with fear.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I must confess it, Sir, without a blush,
(For 'tis no sin to Love) that I cou'd wish—
Heaven and my Father, were inclin'd my way.
But I am all obedience to their wills.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That Sigh was kind,
But ere to morrow this time,
You'll want this pitying sense, and fee • no pantings,
But those which joyes and pleasures do create.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Alas Sir! what is't you'd have me do?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why—I wou'd have you Love, and after that
You need not be instructed what to do.
Give me your Faith▪ give me your Solemn Vow
To be my Wife, and I shall be at peace.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Have you consider'd, Sir, your own condition,
'Tis in your Uncles power to take your Fortune,
If in your choice you disobey his will.
—And Sir, you know that mine is much below you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh I shall calm his Rage,
By urging so much Reason as thy Beauty,
And my own flame, on which my Life depends.
—He now has kindly sent for me to London,
I fear his bus'ness—
Yet if you'll yield to marry me,
We'll keep it secret, till our kinder Stars
Have made provision for the blest discovery▪
Come give me your Vows, or we must part for ever.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Part! oh 'tis a fatal word!
I will do any thing to save that Life,
To which my own so nearly is alli'd.

sp.speaker: Fri • nd.
sp.l: So forward Sister!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Ha! Friendlove!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Was it so kindly done to gain my Sister
Without my knowledge?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Ah Friend! 'Twas from her self alone
That I wou'd take the blessing which I ask.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: And I • ll assist her, Sir, to give it you.
Here take him as an Honour, and be thankful.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I as a blessing sent from Heaven receive her,
And e're I sleep will justifie my Claim,
And make her mine.

sp.speaker: Friend▪
sp.l: Be not so hasty Friend:
Endeavor first to reconcile your Uncle to't.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: By such delayes we're lost: Hast thou forgot?
To morrow she's design'd anothers Bride!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: For that let me alone t' evade.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If you must yet delay me,
Give me leave not to interest such wealth without security.
And I Celinda will instruct you how to satisfie my fears.
sp.stage: [Kneels, and takes her by the hand.
sp.l: Bears witness to my Vows—
May every Plague that Heaven inflicts on Sin,
Fall down in thunder on my head,
If e're I marry any but Celinda,
Or if I do not marry thee fair Maid.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Heartily sworn as I vow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And here I wish as solemnly the same.
—May all arrive to me,
If e're I marry any Man but Bellmour!

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: We are Witnesses as good as a thousand.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But now my Friend, I'de have you take your leave, the day comes on apace, and you • ve not seen your Uncle, since your arrival.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis death to part with thee my fair Celinda,
But our hard Fates, imposes this separation;
—Farewell—Remember thou'rt all mine.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What have I else of joy to think upon—
—Go—go—depart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I will—but 'tis as Misers part with Gold,
Or people full of Health depart from Life.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Go, Sister, to your Bed, and dream of him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Whilst I prepare to meet this Fopp to fight him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hang him, he'll ne're meet thee; to beat a Watch, or kick a Drawer, or batter Windows, is the highest pitch of Valor he e're arriv'd to.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: However I'll expect him, lest he be Fool-hardy enough to keep his word.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Shall I wait on thee?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, no, there • s no need of that—Good morrow my best Friend.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: But e're you go, my dearest Friend and Brother,
Now you are sure of all the joyes you wish
From Heav'n, do not forgetful grow, of that great trust
I gave you of all mine, but like a Friend
Assist me in my great concern of Love
With fair Diana, your lovely Cozen;
You know how long, I have ador'd that Maid,
But still her haughty Pride repell'd my flame,
And all it • fierce efforts

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: She has a spirit equal to her Beauty
As mighty and tyrannick, yet she has goodness,
And I believe enough inclin'd to Love,
When once her Pride's orecome; I have the honour
To be the Confident of all her thoughts:
And to • ugment thy hopes, 'tis not long since,
She did with sighs confess to me, she Lov'd
A Man she said scarce equal to her Fortune;
But all my interest could not learn the Object:
But it must needs be you, by what she said
This I'll improve, and so to your advantage—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: I neither doubt thy Industry, nor Love,
Go and be careful of my Int'rest there,
Whilst I preserve thine as intirely here.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy, Sham and Sharp.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p:
Good morrow Sir Timothy, what not yet ready, and to mee •
Mr. Bellmour at five, the time's past.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: —Ay Pox on't—I han't slep to night for thinking on't.

sp.speaker: Sham▪
sp.p: Well Sir Timothy, I have most excellent News for you, that will do as well, I have found out—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
A new Wench, I warrant—but prethee Sham, I have •• ther matters in hand; 'Sheart I am so mortifi'd with this same though •
of Fighting, that I shall hardly think of Woman kind again.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: You were so forward Sir Timothy—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay Sharp, I am alwayes so when I'm angry; had I been but a little more provok'd then, that we might have gone to't when the heat was brisk, I had done well—but a Pox on't this fighting in cool blood I hate.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: 'Shaw, Sir, 'tis nothing, a Man wou'd do't for Exercise in a morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, if there were no more in't than Exercise; if a Man co • 'd take a Breathing without breathing a Vein—but Sham, this Wounds, and Blood, sounds terribly in my ears; but since thou say'st 'tis nothing, prethee do thou meet Bellmour in my stead; thou art a poor Dog, and 'tis no matter if the world were well rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I wou'd do't with all my Soul—but your Honour Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: —My Honour! 'tis but Custom that makes it Honourable to fight Duels—I warrant you the wise Italian, thinks himself a Man of Honour; and yet when did you hear of an Italian, that ever fought a Duel? Is't not enough, I am affronted, have my Mistriss taken away before my face, hear my self call'd, Dull, Common Man, Dull Animal, and the rest—But I must after all give him leave to kill me too, if he can— And this is your damn'd Honourable English way of shewing a Mans Courage.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I must confess I am of your mind, and therefore have been studying a Revenge, sutable to the Affront: and if I can judge any thing, I have hit it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Hast thou? dear Sham, out with it.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why Sir—what think you of debauching his Sister?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim
sp.p: Why is there such a thing in Nature?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: You know he has a Sister, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes, Rich, and Fair.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Both, or she were not worthy of your Revenge.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh how I love Revenge, that has a double pleasure in it— and where—and where—is this fine piece of temptation?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: In being Sir—but Sharp here, and I, have been at some cost in finding her out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ye shall be overpaid—there's Gold, my little Maquero but she's very handsom?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: As a Goddess, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And art thou sure she will be Lewd?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Are we sure she's a Woman, Sir?—Sure she's in her Teens? has Pride and Vanity—and two or three Sins more, that I cou'd • ame, all which never fails to assist a Woman in Debauchery—But Sir, there are certain people that b • long to her, that must be consider'd too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Stay Sir, e're I part with more money, I'll be certain what returns 'twill make me—that is—I'll see the Wench, not to inform my self, how well I like her, for that I shall do, because she is new, and Bellmours Sister—but to find what possibility there is in gaining her—I am us'd to these things, and can • uess from a look, or a kiss, or a touch of the hand—but then I warrant, 'twill come to the knowledge of Betty Flau • tit.

sp.speaker: Sham▪
sp.p: What Sir—then it seems you doubt us?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: How do you mean, your honesty or judgment?
I can assure you, I doubt both.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How Sir? doubt our honesty?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yes—why I hope neither of you pretend to either, do you?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why, Sir, what do you take us for Cheats?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: As errant, as any's in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: How Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why how now—what flie in my face? are you • stomachs so queasie, that Cheat won't down with you?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why Sir—we are Gentlemen—and tho' our ill Fortunes have thrown us on your Bounty—we are not to be term'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Why you pair of Hectors—whence this impudence?
—De'e you know me ye Raggamuffins?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Yes, but we knew not that you were a Coward before. You talkt big, and huft where e • re you came, like an errant Bully, and so long we Reverenc'd you—but now we find, you have need of our Courage— we'll stand on our Reputations.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: C • urage and Reputation!—h • , ha, ha—why ye lowsie Tatterdemallions —dare ye talk of Courage and Reputation?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Why, Sir, who dares question either?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: He that dares try it.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, hold.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Enough, enough, we are satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: So am not I, ye mangy Mungrels, till I have kickt Courage and Reputation out of ye.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Hold there Sir, • tis enough we are satisfi'd, that you have Courage.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh are you so? then it seems I was not to be believ'd— I told you I had Courage when I was angry.

sp.speaker: Sham
sp.l: Ay Sir, we have prov'd it, and will now swear it.
—But we had an inclination to try Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: And all you did, was but to try my Courage—hah!

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.l: On our Honours nothing else Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim
sp.l: Tho • I know ye to be cursed cowardly lying Rogues,
Y • t because I have use of ye, I must forgive ye.
—Here kiss my hand, and be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: 'Tis an Honour we are proud of Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh is it so Rascallians! then I hope I am to see the Lady without I • dentures.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Oh Lord Sir! any thing we can serve you in.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: And I have brib'd her Maid to bring her this morning into the M • ll.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well, let's about it then; for I am for no Fighting to day— De'e hear Boy—Let the Coach be got ready, whilst I get my self drest

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Coach Sir! Why you know Mr Shatter has pawn'd the Horses.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I had forgot it—A Pox on't, this 'tis to have a Partner in a Coach; By Fortune I must Marry, and set up a whole one.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Mr Charles, your Brother, my young Master Bellmour is come.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I • m glad on't; my Unkle, began to be impatient that he came not, you saying you left him but a dayes journey behind you yesterday. My Unkle has something of importance to say to him, I fansie it may be about a Marriage between him and my Lady Diana—such a whisper I heard—

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I Marry Sir, that were a Match indeed, she being your Unkles onely Heir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Ay but they are Sisters Children, and too near akin to be happy.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p:
'Twere pity my young Master shou'd be unhappy in a Wife; for he is the sweetest natur'd Gentleman—But one comfort is Mr Charles, you, and your Sister Mrs
• hillis, will have your Portions assign'd you • f he Marry.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yes, that he can't deny us the very day after his Marriage.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I shall be glad to see you all dispos'd of well; but I was half afraid, your Brother wou'd have Married Mrs Celinda Friendlove, to whom he made notable Love in Yorkshire, I thought; not but she's a fine Lady; but her Fortune is below that of my young Master • , as much as my Lady Diana's is above his—But see, they come—let us retire, to give 'em leave to talk alone.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
And well Frank, how dost thou find thy self inclin'd, tho •
•• o • 'dst begin to think of something more than Books? Dost thou not
wish to know the joyes that are to be found in a woman Frank? I well remember at thy age I fancy'd a thousand fine things of that kind.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay my Lord, a thousand more perhaps than are to be found.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Not so; but I confess Frank unless the Lady be fair, and there be some Love too, 'tis not altogether so well; therefore I, who am still busie for thy good, have fixt upon a Lady—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha!—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What dost start? Nay, I'll warrant thee she'll please, A Lady rich, and fair, and Nobly born, and thou shalt Marry her Frank.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Marry her my Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why yes Marry her—I hope you are none of the fashionable Fopps, that are alwayes in mutiny against Marriage, who never think themselves very witty, but when they rail against Heav'n and a Wife— But Frank, I have found better Principles in thee, and thou hast the Reputation of a sober young Gentleman, thou art besides a Man of great Fortune Frank.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And therefore Sir, ought the less to be a Slave.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But Frank, we are made for one another, and ought by the Laws of God, to communicate our blessings▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, there are Men enough, fitter much than I, to obey those Laws, nor do I think them made for every one.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
But Frank, you do not know what a Wife I have provided fo •
you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis enough I know she's a Woman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: A Woman, why what should she be else?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: An Angel, Sir, e're she can be my Wife.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: In good time, but this is a Mortal Sir—and must serve your turn—but Frank, she is the finest Mortal—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I humbly beg your pardon, if I tell you,
That had she Beauty such as Heav'n ne're made,
Nor meant again t' inrich a Woman with,
It cou'd not take my heart.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: But Sir, perhaps you do not guess the Lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Or cou'd I Sir, it cou'd not change my nature.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: But Sir, suppose it be my Neece Diana.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: How Sir? the fair Diana.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I thought thou'dst come about again;
What think you now of Woman-kind, and Wedlock?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: As I did before, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What, thou canst not think I am in earnest, I confess Frank, she is above thee in point of Fortune, she being my onely Heir—but suppose 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh I'm undone—Sir I dare not suppose so greatly in favour of my self.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But Frank, you must needs suppose—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh I am ruin'd, lost, for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I mean I cannot Marry fair Diana.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Death how's this?—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She is a thing, above my humble wishes—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Is that all? take you no care for that, for she loves you already, and I have resolv'd it which is better yet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Love me Sir? I know she cannot,
And Heav'n forbid that I should injure her.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Sir, this is a put-off: resolve quickly, or I'll compel you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You wou • d not use extremity,
What is the forfeit of my disobedience?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The loss of all your Fortune,
If you refuse the Wife I have provided—
Especially a handsom Lady, • s she is Frank.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh me unhappy!
What cursed Laws provided this severity?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Even those of your Fathers disposal, who seeing so many examples, in this lewd Age, of the ruine of whole Families, by imprudent Marriages, provided otherwise for you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But Sir, admit Diana be inclin'd,
And I (by my unhappy Stars so curst)
Should be unable to accept the Honour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: How Sir? admit?—I can no more admit,
Than you can suppose—therefore give me your final answer.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir, can you think a blessing e're can fall
Upon that Pair, whom Interest joins, not Love.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Why what's in Diana that you shou'd not love her?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I must confess she has a thousand Virtues,
The least of which wou'd bless another Man;
But Sir, I hope if I am so unhappy
As not to love that Lady, you will pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Indeed Sir but I will not, love me this Lady, and marry me this Lady, or I will teach you what it is to refuse such a Lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir, tis not in my power to obey you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: How? not in your pow'r?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: No, Sir, I see my fatal r • ine in your eyes,
And know too well your force, and my own misery.
—But Sir—when I shall tell you who I've married—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Who you've married!—By all that's Sacred if that be true, thou art undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh hear me Sir!
I came with hopes to have found you merciful.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Expect none from me; no, thou shalt not have so much of thy
Estate, as will afford thee Bread.
By Heaven thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh pity me, my Lord, pity my Youth;
It is no Beggar, nor none basely born
That I have given my heart • o, but a Maid,
Whose Birth, whose Beauty, and whose Education,
Merits the best of Men.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Very fine! where is the Priest that durst dispose of you, without my order? Sirrah you are my slave—at least your whole Estate is at my mercy—and besides, I'll charge you with an Action of 5000 l. for your ten Years maintenance: Do you know that this is in my pow'r too?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, and dread your Anger worse than death.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Oh Villain! thus to dash my expectation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir, on my bended knees, thus low I fall
To beg your mercy.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, I will have mercy,
I • ll give you Lodging—but in a Dungeon Sir,
Where you shall ask your food of Passers by.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: All this, I know you have the power to do,
But, Sir, were I thus cruel, this hard usage
Would give me cause to execute it.
I wear a Sword, and I dare right my self;
And Heav'n wou'd pardon it, if I should kill you:
But Heav'n forbid, I shou'd correct that Law,
Which gives you power, and orders me obedience.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, I shall • ame that Courage, and punish that Harlot, who e're she be, that has seduc'd ye.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: How Harlot, Sir!—Death such another word,
And through all Laws and Reason I will rush,
And reach thy Soul, if mortal like thy Body.
—No Sir, she's Chaste, as are the new-made Vows,
I breath'd upon her Lips, when last we parted.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Who waits there?
—Shall I be murder'd in my own House?
'Tis time you were remov'd—
Go get an Action of 5000 l. enter'd against him;
With Officers to Arrest him.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.l: My Lord, 'tis my young Master Bellmour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ye all dote upon him▪ but he's not the Man you take him for.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.l: How my Lord? not this Mr Bellmour?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Dogs obey me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Stay Sir—oh stay—what will become of me?
'Twere better that my Life were lost than Fortune—
For that being gone, Celinda must not love me.
—But to die wretchedly—
—Poorly in Prison—whilst I can manage this—
—Is below him, that does adore Celinda.
—I'll kill my self—but then—I kill Celinda.
—Shou'd I obey this Tyrant—then too she dies.
—Yes Sir—You may be cruel—take the Law,
—And kill me quickly, 'twill become your justice.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Was I call'd back for this? Yes, I shall take it Sir, do not fear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yet, stay Sir—Have you lost all Humanity?
Have you no Se • se of Honour, nor of Horrors!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Away with him—go, be gone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Stay Sir! oh God! what is't you'd have me do?
—Here—I resign my self unto your will—
But oh Celinda!—what will become of thee!
—Yes, I will Marry—and Diana too.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis well you will, had I been good natur'd now,
You had been undone, and mist Diana too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But must I Marry?—Needs Marry Sir?—
Or lose my Fortune, and my Liberty,
Whil'st all my Vows are given to another?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: By all means, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bel • .
sp.l: If I must Marry any but Celinda,
I shall not, Sir, enjoy one moments bliss!
I shall be quite unman'd, Cruel and Brutal!
A Beast, unsafe for Woman to converse with;
Besides, Sir, I have given my Heart and Faith,
And any second Marriage is Adultery.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Heart and Faith, I am glad 'tis no worse; if the Ceremony of the Church has not past, 'tis well enough.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All Sir, that Heaven, and Love requires, is past.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Thou art a Fool Frank, come—dry thy Eyes,
And receive Diana.—Trusty— Call in my Neece.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yet Sir relent, be kind, and save my soul.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No more—by Heaven, if you resist my Will, I'll make a strange example of thee, and of that Woman, who e're she be, that drew thee to this folly. Faith and Vows quoth ye.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Then I obey.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Look ye here Frank, is this a Lady to be dislik'd?
Come hither Frank—Trusty— Haste for Dr. Tickletext, my Chaplain's not in Town; I'll have them instantly Married—Come hither Diana— Diana, will you Marry your Cozen Frank Bellmour?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Yes, if it be your pleasure; Heaven cou'd not let fall a greater blessing.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And you Frank, will you Marry my Neece Diana?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Since you will have it so.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Come follow me then, and you shall be both pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh my Celinda—
To preserve thee, what is't I wou'd not do,
Forfeit my Heaven, nay more I forfeit you.

div.head: Scene 4. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy Tawdrey, S • am and Sharp.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Now Sham, art not thou a damn'd lying Rogue, to make me
• aunter up and down the Mall all this morning, after a Woman that thou knowst in thy Conscience was not likely to be there?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why Sir—if her Maid will be a jilting Whore, how can I help it—Sharp— Thou knowst we presented her handsomly, and she protested she'd do't.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ay, Ay Sir [Aside] but the Devil a Maid we saw.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Sir, it may be Things have so fallen out, that she could not possibly come.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Things! a Pox of your Tricks—Well, I see there's no trusting a poor Devil—Well, what device will your Rogueship find out to Cheat me next?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Prethee help me out at a dead Lift Sharp.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Cheat you Sir!—If I been't reveng'd on this She-Counsellor of the Patching and Painting, this Letter-in of Midnight Lovers, this Receiver of Bribes for stol'n Pleasures; may I be condemn'd never to make Love to any thing of higher quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no Threatning Sharp, it may be she's Innocent yet—Give her t'other Bribe, and try what that will do.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'll have no more to do with frail Woman, in this case, I have a surer way to do your business.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Is not that Bellmour's Page?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: It is Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: By Fortune the Rogue's looking for me; he has a Challenge in his hand too.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: No matter, Sir, Huff it out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim
sp.p: Prethee do thee Huff him, thou knowst the way on't.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: What's your bus'ness with Sir Timothy Sir?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Mine Sir, I don't know the Gentleman, pray which is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I, I,'t is so—Pox on him.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well, Boy, I am he—what—Your Master—

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My Master Sir—

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Are not you Bellmour's Page?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Well, your News.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: News Sir? I know of none, but of my Masters being this morning—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, there it is—behind Southampton House.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Married▪ this morning

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How? Marry'd! 'Slife, has he serv'd me so?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: The Boy is drunk—Bellmour Married!

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes indeed, to the Lady Diana.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Diana! Mad by Fortune; what Diana?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Neece to the Lord Plotwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Come hither Boy—Art thou sure of this?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, I am sure of it; and I am going to bespeak Musick for the Ball anon.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What hast thou there—a Letter to the Divine Celinda; A dainty Boy—there's money for thee to buy Nickers.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Sh • rp.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if this be true, Celinda will be glad of you again.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, but I will have none of her—For, look you Sham, there is but two sorts of Love in this World—Now I am sure the Rogue did love her; and since it was not to Marry her, it was for the thing you wot on, as appears by his writing to her now—But yet I will not believe what this Boy said till I see it,

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I have thought of a thing, that may both clear your doubt, and give us a little mirth.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I conceive thee.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I know y'are quick of apprehension, Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: O your servant dear Sham—But to let thee see I am none of the dullest, we are to Jigg it in Masquerade this evening, hah.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you have it, and there you may have an opportunity to Court Bellmour's sister.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis a good motion, and we will follow it; send to the Dukes House, and borrow some Habits presently.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I'll about it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Make haste to my Lodging—But heark ye—not a word of
this to Betty • launtit,
• he'll be up in Arms these two dayes, if she go not with us; and tho • I think the fond Devil is true to me, yet • twere worse than Wedlock, if I should be so to her to.
sp.l: Tho' Whores in all things else the Mast'ry get,
In this alone, like Wives, they must submit.

div.trailer: The End of the • Second Act.

div.head: Scene 1. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Lord Plotwell, Bellmour leading in Diana, follow'd by Charles Bellmour, Phillis, and other Ladies and Gentlemen.
[Musick play • s, till they are all seated.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: HEre Nephew, I resign that Trust which was repos'd in me by your dead Father, which was that on your Wedding day, I should thus—make you Master of your whole Fortune, you being Married to my liking—And now Charles, and you my Neece Phillis, you may demand your Portions to morrow, if you please, for he is oblig'd to pay you the day after that of his Marriage.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: There's time enough my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Come, come Ladies, in tro • h you must take but little rest to night, in complasance to the Bride, and Bridegroom, who I believe, will take but little—Frank—why Frank—what hast thou chang'd thy humor with thy condition? thou wert not wont to hear the Musick play in vain.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My Lord, I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Indeed you're wondrous sad.
And I methinks too▪ bear thee company.
I know not why, and yet excess of joy,
Have had the same effects with equal grief.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and I have now felt the extremes of both.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why Nephew Charles—has your breeding at the Academy instructed your heels in no motion?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My Lord, I'll make one.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: And I another, for joy that my Brother's made happy in so fair a Bride.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Hell take your ignorance, for thinking I am happy,
—Wou'd Heav • n wou'd strike me dead.
That by the loss of a poor wretched life,
I might preserve my soul—but oh my erro!
That has already damn'd it self, when it consented
To break a Sacred Vow, and Marry here.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Come, come begin, begin, Musick to your office.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why does not this hard heart, this stubborn Fugitive
Break with this Load of Griefs; but like ill Spirits
It promis'd fair, till it had drawn me in,
And then betray'd me to Damnation.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: There's something in disorder in his Soul,
Which I'm on fire, to know the meaning of.

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy, Sham and Sharp in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: The Rogue is Married, and I am so pleas'd, I can forgive him our last Nights quarrel; prithee Sharp, if thou canst learn that young things name, 'tis a pretty airy Rogue, whil • st I go talk to her.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.l: I will, Sir, I will.

div.stage: [One goes • to take out a Lady.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, you must dance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I hope you will not call it Rudeness, Madam, if I refuse you here.
sp.stage: [The Lady that danc't, goes to take out the Bridegroom. After the Dance▪ she takes out Sir Timothy, they walk a C • rrant.
sp.l: Am I still tame and patient with my ills?
Gods! What is Man? That he can live and bare
Yet know his pow'r to rid himself of grief
I will not live, or if my destiny
Compel me to't, it shall be worse than dying.

div.stage: Enter Page with a Table Book.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: The answer of a Letter, Sir, you sent to the Divine Celinda; for so it was directed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: —Hah—Celinda—in my crowd of thoughts
I had forgot I sent—come nearer Boy—
—What did she say to thee?—Did she not smile?
And use thee with contempt and scorn—tell me.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: How scorn, Sir!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: —Or she was angry—call'd me perjur'd Villain—
False, and forsworn—nay, tell me truth.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thou dost delay me—say she did, and please me.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Again—tell me, what answer Rascal did she send me?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: You have it, Sir, there in the Table Book.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh I am mad, and know not what I do.
—Prithee forgive me Boy—take breath my Soul
Before thou dost begin; for this—perhaps may be
So cruel kind.
To leave thee none when thou hast ended it.

body.head: LETTER.
body.l: I Have took in the Poyson which you sent, in these few
Fatal words—Forgive me my Celinda, I am Married—
'Twas thus you said—And I have only Life left to return—
—Forgive me my sweet Bellmour—I am dead.

sp.l: —Can I hear this, and live?—I am a Villain!
In my Creation destin'd for all mischief.
—To commit Rapes, and Murders, to break Vows,
As fast as Fools do Jests.
Come hither Boy—
And said the Lady nothing to thee?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes—e're she read the Letter, ask'd your health,
And joy disperst it self, in blushes through her cheeks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Her b • auty makes the very Boy adore it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: And having read it,
She drew her Tablets from her Pocket,
And trembling—writ what I have brought you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Tho' I before had loaded up my Soul
With sins, that wou'd have weigh'd down any other,
Yet this one more it bears, this sin of Murder.
And holds out still—What have I more to do,
But being plung'd in, in blood, to wade it through.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: There stands the Traytor with a guilty look,
That Traytor, who the easier to deceive me,
Betray'd my Sister; yet till I came and saw
The Perjury, I could not give a Faith to't.
—By Heaven, Diana, loves him, nay dotes on him,
I find it in her Eyes, all languishing
They feed the fire in his, arm'd with a double Rage,
I know I shall go through with my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Fair Maid—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: How do you know that Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I see y'are fair, and I guess you're a Maid.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Your guess, is better than your eye-sight, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What e're you are, by Fortune, I wish you would permit me to love you with all faults.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: You? Pray who are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A Man, a Gentleman—and more, a Knight too, by Fortune.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Then 'twas not by merit Sir—But how shall I know you are either of these?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That I'm a Man, the effects of my vigorous • f • ame shall prove— a Gentleman my Coat of Arms shall testifie, and I have the Kings Patent for my Title.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: For the first you may thank your Youth, for the next your Father, and the last your Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: By Fortune, I love thee for thy pertness.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Is it possible you can love at all?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: As much as I dare.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: How de ye mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Not to be laught a • ; 'tis not the Mode to love much: A Platonick Fopp, I have heard of, but this is an Age of sheere enjoyment, and little Love goes to that; we have found it incommode, and loss of time, to make long Addresses.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I find, Sir, you and I shall never agree upon this matter.
But, see Sir, here • s more company.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh Heav'n! 'tis true, these Eyes confirm my Fate.
Yonder he is—and that fair splendid thing
That gazes on him with such kind desire,
Is my blest Rival—oh he is Married.
—Gods! and yet you let him live!
Live too with all his Charms, as fine and gay,
As if you meant he shou'd undo▪ all easie Maids.
And kill 'em for their sin of loving him.
Wretched Celinda!
But I must turn my Eyes from looking on;
The fatal triumphs of my death—Which of all these
Is my Brother? Oh this is he; I know him
By the Habit he sent for to the Play-house.
And hither he's come in Masquerade,
I know with some design against my Bellmour▪
Whom tho' he kill me, I must still preserve.
Whil'st I, lost in despair, thus as a Boy
Will seek a Death from any welcome hand,
Since I want Courage, to perform the Sacrifice.

div.stage: Enter one and dances an Entry, and a Iigg, at the end on't▪

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Enough, enough at this time, let's see the Bride to Bed, the Bridegroom thinks it long.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Hell! Can I endure to hear all this with patience?
Shall he depart with Life to enjoy my Right,
And to deprive my Sister of her due?
—Stay—Stay—and resign
That Virgin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who art thou, that dar'st lay a claim to ought that's here?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: This Sword shall answer ye.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Tho' I cou'd spare my Life, I'll not be rob'd on't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh my dear Bellmour!

div.stage: All draw on Bellmour's side—Diana holds Bellmour, Celinda runs between their Swords, and defends Bellmour; Sir Tim. Sham and Sharp draw, and run into several corners, with signs of fear.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Who art thou that thus fondly guard'st his heart?
—Be gone—and let me meet it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That thou may'st do through mine, but no way else.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Here are too many to encounter, and I'll defer my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Stay Sir, we must not part so.
sp.stage:
[Ex. Drawing at the • ame door,
• hat Sir • Tim. is sneaking out at.
sp.l: Come back I say.
Slave! dost thou tremble?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Sir, I'm not the Man you look for—
By Fortune, Sham, we're all undone!
He has mistook me for the fighting Fellow.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Villain! defend thy Life!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Who I Sir? I have no quarrel to you, nor no Man breathing, not I, by Fortune.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: This Coward cannot be my Brother!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What made thee draw upon my Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Who? I Sir? by Fortune I love him—I draw upon him!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I do not wonder thou canst lye, for thou' •• a Coward!
Did • not thou draw upon him? Is not thy Sword yet out?
Did I not see thee fierce, and active too, as if thou hadst dar'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why he's gone Sir; a Pox of all Mistakes, and Masqueradings I say—this was your Plot Sham.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Coward! shew then thy face.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'll be hang • d first, by Fortune; for then 'twill be plain 'twas I, because I challeng'd Bellmour last night, and broke my assignation this morning.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Shew thy face without delay, or—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: My face, Sir, I protest, by Fortune, 'tis not worth seeing.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Then Sirra, you are worth a kicking—take that—and that—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How Sir? how?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: So Sir, so.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Have a care Sir—by Fortune, I shall fight with a little more.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Take that to raise you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Nay then I am angry, and I dare fight.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Go, Ladies, see the Bride to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The Knight, Sir Timothy Tawdrey,
—The Rascal mist me at the appointed place,
And comes to attack me here.—
—Brave Youth! I know not how
I came to merit this Relief from thee.
Sure thou'rt a stranger to me, thou'rt so kind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, I believe those happy ones that know you
Had been far kinder, but I'm indeed a stranger.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: May'st thou be ever so, to one so wretched;
I will not ask thy name, lest knowing it,
(I am such a Monster) I should ruine thee.

sp.speaker: Cel▪
sp.l: Oh how he melts my Soul! I cannot stay,
Lest Grief, my Sex, and Bus'ness shou'd betray.
—Farewell Sir—
—May you be happy in the Maid you love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh dost thou mock my griefs—by Heaven he did.
—Stay Sir—he's gone.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The Rogue took courage, when he saw there was not remedy; but there's no hurt done on either side.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: 'Tis fit such as he shou'd be chastis'd, that do abuse Hospitality. Come, come, to Bed, the Lady, Sir, expects you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Gentlemen, good night.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I long to know the cause of Bellmour's disorder to night,
And here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Bellmour, Lord, Charles, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Shan't we see you laid Brother?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes in my Grave, dear Charles,
But I'll excuse that Ceremony here.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good night, and no rest to you Brother.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Till now my Bellmour, I wanted opportunity
To ask the cause, why on a joyful day,
When Heaven has join'd us, by a sacred tye,
Thou droopst like early Flowers, with Winter storms.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thou art that Winter storm, that nips my Bud,
All my young springing hopes, my gay desires,
The prospect of approaching joyes of Love,
Thou in a hapless minute hast took from me,
And in its room,
Hast given me an eternal desperation.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Have you then given me Vows ye can repent of?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I given ye Vows! be witness ye just Powers!
How far I was from giving any Vows:
No, no, Diana, I had none to give!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: No Vows to give!
What were they which to the holy Man
Thou didst repeat, when I was made all thine?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The effects of low submission! such as Slaves
Condemn'd to dye, yield to the angry Judge.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Dost thou not love me then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Love thee! no by Heaven! yet wish I were so happy.
For thou art wondrous fair, and wondrous good!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh what a defeat is here!
The onely Man, who from all Natures store
I found most charming, fit for my desires,
And now after a thousand expectations,
Such as all Maids that Love like me do hope,
Just ready for the highest joyes of Love!
Then to be met thus cold—nay worse with scorn.
—Why since you could not love me, did you marry me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Because I was a Beast! a very Villain▪
That stak'd, a wretched Fortune, to all my joyes of Life.
And like a prodigal Gamester lost that all.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: How durst you, Sir, knowing my Quality,
Return me this false Pay, for Love so true?
—Was this a Beauty, Sir, to be neglected?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Fair angry Maid, frown on, frown till you kill,
And I shall dying bless those Eyes that did so.
For shou'd I live, I shou'd deprive the happier World
Of treasures, I am too wretched to possess.
And wer't not pity that vast store of Beauty,
Shou'd like rich Fruit, dye on the yielding Boughs.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And are you then resolv'd to be a stranger to me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: For ever! for a long Eternity.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh thou'st undone me then; hast thou found out
A Maid more fair, more worthy of thy Love?
Look on me well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I have consider'd thee,
And find no blemish in thy • oul, or Form,
Thou art all o're Divine, yet I must hate thee,
Since thou hast drawn me to a mortal sin,
That cannot be forgiven, by Men, or Heaven:
—Oh thou hast made me break a Vow Diana,
A Sacred Solemn Vow,
And m • de me wrong the sweetest Innocence,
That ever blest the Earth.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Instead of cooling, this augments my fire,
No pain is like defeated, new desire.
'Tis false, or but to try my Constancy.
Your Mistriss is not so Divine as I,
And shou'd I, 'gainst himself believe the Man
Who first inspir'd my heart with Loves soft flame!

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.l: What bliss on me insensible you throw,
I'de rather hear thee swear, thou art my Foe,
And like some Noble and Romantick Maid
With Poniards, wou'd my stubborn heart invade,
And whil'st thou dost the faithful Relique tear,
In every Vein thoud'st find Celinda there.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Come, Sir, you must forget Celinda's Charms,
And reap delights within my circling Arms,
Delights that may your Errors undeceive
When you find joyes, as great as she can give.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What do I hear?—Is this the kind relief
Thou dost allow to my despair and grief?
Is this the comfort that thou dost impart
To my all wounded, bleeding, dying heart?
Were I so Brutal—cou'd thy Love comply
To serve it self with base Adultery?
For cou'd I love thee, cou'd I love agen,
Our Lives wou'd be but one continued Sin;
A Sin of that black die▪ a Sin so foul,
'Twould leave no hopes of Heav'n for eithers Soul.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Dull Man▪ Dost think a feeble vain Excu ••
Shall satisfie me for this Nights abuse?
No, since my Passion, thou'st defeated thus,
And rob'd me of my long wish'd happiness▪
I'll make thee know what a wrong'd Maid can do,
Divided 'twixt her Love, and Injuries too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I dare thy worst
Shou'd Hell assist thy aims, thou cou'dst not find
New Plagues, unless thou shou'dst continue kind,
Hard Fate Diana, when thy Love must be
The greatest Curse that can arrive to me.
—That friendship which our Infant years begun,
And till this day has still continued on,
I will preserve, and my Respects shall be
Profound, as what was ever paid by me.
But for my Love 'tis to Celinda due,
And I can pay you • one that's just and true.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The rest, I • de have thee know I do despise,
I better understand my conquering Eyes:
Those Eyes that shall revenge my Love and Shame,
I'll kill thy Reputation, and thy Name.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My Honour! And my Reputation, now!
They both were forfeit, when I broke my Vow.
Nor cou'd my Honour with thy Fame decline,
Whoe're prophanes thee, injures nought of mine.
This night upon the Couch my self I'll lay,
And▪ like Franciscans, let th' ensuing day
Take care for all the toils it brings with it,
Whatever Fate arrives, I can submit.

div.head: The Scene a Street.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not one kind Wound to send me to my Grave,
And yet between their angry Swords I • an,
Expecting it from Bellmour, or my Brothers.
Oh my hard Fate! that gave me so much Misery,
And dealt no Courage, to prevent the shock.
