—Why came • off alive, that fatal place
Where I beheld my Bellmour, in th' embrace
Of my extremely fair, and lovely Rival;
—With what kind care she did prevent my Arm
(Who greedy of the last sad pa • ting twine)
I wou'd have thrown about him, as if she knew
To what intent I made the passionate offer.
—What have I next to do, but seek a death
Where ever I can meet it—Who comes here?

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy, Sham and Sharp, with Fidlers and Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I believe this is the Bed-chamber Window where the Bride and the Bridegroom lies.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Well, and what do you intend to do, if it be Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why first sing a Bawdy Song, and then break the Windows, in Revenge for the Affront was put upon me to night.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, that's but a poor Revenge, and which every Footman may take of his Lady, who has turn'd him away for filching— You know, Sir, Windows are frail, and will yield to the lusty Brick-bats; 'tis an Act below a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That's all one, 'tis my Recreation; I serv'd a Woman so the other night, to whom my Mistriss had a Pique.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: Ay, Sir, 'tis a Revenge fit only for a Whore to take—
And the Affront you receiv'd • o night, was by mistake.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Mistake! how can that be?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why, Sir, did you not mind, that he that drew upon Bellmour, was in the same dress with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How shou'd his be like mine?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why by the same chance, that yours was like his—I suppose sending to the Play-house for them, as we did, they hapned to send him such another • abit, for they have many such for dancing Shepherds.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well I grant it a mistake, and that shall repri • ve the Windows.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you shew'd so much courage, that you may bless the minute that forc'd you to fight.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, but between you and I, 'twas well he kick'd me first, and made me angry, or I had been • ustily swing'd, by Fortune—but thanks to my spleen that sav'd my bones that • bou • —but then I did well —hah! came briskly off, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: With honour▪ Sir, I protest.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim
sp.p: Come then, we'll Serenade him. Come, Sirra, • une your Pipes, and sing.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What shall I sing, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Any thing sutable to the time and place.

lg.l: The happy Minute's come, the Nymph is laid,
Who means no more to rise a Maid
Blushing, and panting, she expects the approch
Of Ioyes that kill with every touch;
Nor can her Native modesty and shame
Conceal the Ardour of her Virgin flame.
And now the Amorous Youth is all undrest,
Iust ready for Loves mighty Feast,
With vigorous haste the Vail aside he throws,
That does all Heaven at once disclose;
Swift as desire, into her naked Arms
Himself he throws, and rifles all her Charms.

sp.p: God morrow Mr. Bellmour, and to your lovely Bride, long may you live, and love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who is't, has sent that Curse?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What a pox is that Bellmour? The Rogue's in choler, the Bride has not pleas'd him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Dogs! De you upbraid me? •• ll be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Will you so—but I'll not stay your coming.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But you shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Turn Villains!

div.stage:
[Sir Tim. &c. offers to go off, Celinda steps forth, and draws, they draw, and s • t upon her. Enter Bellmour behind them: They turn, and Celinda sides with Bellmour, and fights. Enter Dia. Bellmour
• igh •• 'em out, and leaves Celinda breathless, lea • ing on her Sword.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I'll ne'r demand the cause of this disorder,
But take this opportunity to flie
To the next hands will take me up—who's here!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not yet, my sullen heart!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Who's here? one wounded—alas—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis not so lucky—but who art thou
That dost with so much pity, ask?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He seems a Gentleman—handsom, and young—
Pray ask no questions, Sir, but if you're what you seem,
Give a Protection to an unhappy Maid.
—Do not reply, but let us haste away.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Hah—What do I hear! sure 'tis Diana.
—Madam, with haste, and joy, I'll serve you.
—I'll carry her to my own Lodgings.
Fortune, in this, 〈◊〉 done my Suff'rings right,
My Rival's in my Power, upon her Wedding night.

div.stage: Enter Bellmour, Sir Tim. Sham and Sharp.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, that you should not know, your friend and humble servant, Tim. Tawdrey—But thou lookst as if thou hadst not been a Bed yet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No more I have.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay then thou losest precious time, I'll not detain thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tho • art mistaken, I hate all Woman-kind—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How, how!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Above an hour—heark ye Knight—I am as lewd, and as debaucht as thou art.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What do you mean Franck?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: To tell a truth, which yet I never did.
—I Whore, Drink, Game, Swear, Lye, Cheat, Rob, Pimp, Hector, All,
All I do that's vicious.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Bless me!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: From such a Villain, hah!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, but that thou shouldst hide it all this while.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Till I was married only, and now I can dissemble it no longer— come—let's to a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: A Bawdy-house! What already!
This is the very qui • tessence of L • wdness.
—Why I thought that I was wicked, but by Fortune,
This dashes mine quite out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh thou'rt a puny sinner!—I'll teach thee Arts▪ (so rare) of sin, the least of them shall damn thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: By Fortune, Franck, I do not like these Arts.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then thou'rt a Fool—I'll teach thee to be rich too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, that I like.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Look here my Boyes!
sp.stage: [Holds up his Writings—which he takes out of his Pockets.
sp.l: The Writings of 3000 l. a year.
—All this I got by Perjury.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: By Fortune a thriving Sin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And we will live in Sin while this holds out.
—And then to my cold Home—Come let's • e gone.
—O • that I • e'r might see the Rising Sun.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Discovers Celinda as before sitting in a Chair, Diana by her in another, who sings.

lg.l: Celinda, who did Love disdain,
For whom had languish'd many a Swain,
Leading her bleating Flocks to drink,
She spy'd upon the Rivers brink
A Youth, whose Eyes did well declare
How much he lov'd, but lov'd not her.
At first she laugh'd, but gaz'd the while,
And soon it lessen'd to a smile;
Thence to surprize▪ and wonder came
Her Breast to heave, her Heart to flame;
Then cry'd she out, Ah now I prove
Thou art a God! Almighty Love.
She wou'd have spoke, but Shame deny'd,
And bad her first consult her Pride;
But soon she found that Aid was gone,
For Love, alas! had left her none.
Oh how she burns, but 'tis too late,
For in his Eyes, she reads her Fate.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh how numerous are her Charms—
—How shall I pay this generous condescension,
F • ir lovely Maid—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why do you flatter Sir?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To say you're lovely, by your self I do not,
I'm young, and have not mu • h converst with Beauty,
Yet I'll esteem my judgment, since it knows,
Where my devotions, shou'd be justly paid.
—But Madam, may I • not yet expect
To hear the Story, you so lately promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I owe much to your goodness, Sir—but—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am too young, you think, to hear a Secret;
Can I want Sence to pity your Misfortunes,
Or Passion to incite me to revenge 'em?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh would he were in earnest!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She's fond of me, and I must blow that flame,
Do any thing to make her hate my Bellmour.
—But Madam, I'm impatient for your Story,
That after that, you may expect my service.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The Treatment you this Night have given a distressed Maid, enough obliges me; nor need I tell you, I m Nobly born, something about my dress, my looks and meen, will doubtless do me reason.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sufficiently—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
But in the Family where I was Educated, a Youth of my own Age, a Kinsman too, I ch • nc'd to fall in Love with; but with a Passion my Pride still got the better of, and he, I thought, repaid my young desires:
but Bashfulness on his part, did what Pride had done on mine, and kept his too conceal'd.—At last my Uncle, who had the absolute dominion of us both, thought good to Marry us together.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Punish him Heav'n, for a Sin so great.
—And are you Married then?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why is there Terror in that word?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: By all that's Sacred, 'tis a word that kills me,
Oh say thou art not;
And I, thus low wil • fall, and pay thee Thanks.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: You'll wish indeed I were not, when you know
How very, very wretched it has made me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Should you be telling me a Tale all day,
Such as would melt a heart that ne'r could love,
'Twould not increase my Reason for the wish
That I had dy'd e're known you had been Married.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: So many soft words from my Bellmour's mouth
Had made me mad with joy, and next to that,
I wish to hear 'em from this Youth;
If they be real, how I shall be reveng'd!
—But why at my being Married should you sigh?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Because I love, is that a Wonder, Madam?
Have you not Charms sufficient at first sight
To wound a heart tender and young as mine?
Are you not heavenly fair?—oh there's my grief—
—Since you must be anothers.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Pray hear me out, and if you love me after,
Perhaps you may not think your self unhappy.
When Night was come, she long'd for Night, and all
Retir'd to give us silent room for joy.—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh I can hear no more!—by Heav'n I cannot.
—Here—stab me to the heart—let out my life,
I cannot live, and hear what follow'd next.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Pray hear me Sir—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh you will tell me he was kind—
Yes, yes—oh God—were not his balmy Kisses,
Sweeter than Incence offer'd up to Heaven?
Did not his Arms softer and whiter far,
Than those of Ioves, transform'd to Wings of Swans,
Greedily clasp thee round—oh quickly speak,
Whil'st thy fair rising Bosome met with his;
And then—oh—then—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Alas Sir! What's the matter—sit down awhile.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now—I am well—pardon me lovely Creature,
If I betray a Passion, I'm too young
To've learnt the Art of hiding:
—I cannot hear you say that he was kind.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Kind, yes, as Blasts to Flow'rs, or early Fruit;
All gay I met him full of youthful heat,
But like a damp, he dasht my kindled flame,
And all his Reason was—he lov'd another,
A Maid he call'd Celinda.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh blessed Man!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To leave thee free, to leave thee yet a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yes, I have vow'd he never shall possess me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh how you bless me—but you still are Married,
And whil'st you are so—I must languish—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Oh how his softness moves me!
—But can all this disorder spring from Love?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Or may I still prove wretched.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And can you think there are no wayes
For me to gratifie that Love?
What wayes am I constrain'd to use to work out my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How mean you Madam?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Without a Miracle, look on my Eyes—
—And Beauty—which you say can kindle Fires,
—She that can give—may too retain desires.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She'll Ravish me—let me not understand you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Look on my Wrongs—
Wrongs that would melt a frozen Chastity,
That a Religious Vow had made to Heaven.
—And next survey thy own perfections.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Hah—

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Art thou so young, thou canst not apprehend me?
Fair bashful Boy, hast thou the pow'r to move,
And yet not know the bus'ness of thy Love?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How in an instant, thou hast chill d my blood,
And made me know no Woman can be good?
'Tis Sin enough to yield—but thus to sue
Heaven—'tis my bus'ness—and not meant for you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: How little Love is understood by thee,
'Tis Custom, and not Passion, you pursue;
Because enjoyment first was nam'd by me,
It does destroy, what shou'd your flame renew;
My easie yielding does your fire abate,
And mine, as much your tedious Courtship hate.
Tell Heaven—you will hereafter sacrifice,
—And see how that will please the Deities:
The ready Victim, is the Noblest way,
Your Zeal and Obligations too, to pay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I think the Gods wou'd hardly be ador'd,
If they their blessings shou'd unaskt afford,
And I that Beauty can no more admire
Who e're I sue, can yield to my desire.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Dull Youth farewell,
For since 'tis my Revenge that I pursue
Less Beauty, and more Man, as well may do.

div.stage: Enter Friendlove disguis'd, as one from a Camp.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Madam you must not go with this mistake.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Celinda, has inform'd me true—'tis she—
Good morrow Brother, what so early at your devotions?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O my Brother's come, and luckily relieves me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Your Orizons are made to a fair Saint.
—Pray Sir what Lady's that?
Or is it blasphemy to repeat her name?
—By my bright Arms, she's fair—With what a charming
Fierceness, she charges through my body to my heart.
—Death how her glitt'ring Eyes give fire, and wound!
And have already pierc'd my very Soul!
—May I approach her Brother?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, if you dare, there's danger in it tho',
She has Charms that will bewitch you.
—I dare not stand their mischief.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: —Lady—I am a Soldier—yet in my gentlest terms
I humbly beg to kiss your lovely hands—
—Death! there's Magick in the touch.
By Heaven you carry an Artillery in every part.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: This is a Man indeed fit for my purpose.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Nay do not view me, I am no lovely object.
I am a Man bred up to Noise and War,
And know not how to dress my looks in smiles;
Yet trust me, fair one, I can love and serve
As well as an Endymion, or Adonis.
Wou'd you were willing to permit that service.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why Sir?—What cou'd you do?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Why—I cou'd die for you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I need the service of the living, Sir.
But do you love me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Or let me perish, flying from a single Enemy.
I am a Gentleman, and may pretend to love you,
And what you can command, I can perform.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Take heed Sir, what you say, for I'm in earnest.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Command me any thing that's just and brave,
And by my Eyes 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I know not what you call just, or brave,
But those whom I do the honour to command,
Must not capitulate.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Let him be blasted with the name of Coward,
That dares dispute your orders.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Dare you fight for me?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: With a whole Army; 'tis my Trade to fight.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis but a single Man.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Name him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Bellmour.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Of Yorkshire?—Companion to young Friendlove, that came lately from Italy?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yes, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: I do, who has oft spoke of Bellmour;
We Travel'd into Italy together—But since, I hear,
He fell in Love with a fair cruel Maid,
For whom he languishes,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Heard you her name?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Diana, rich in Beauty, as in Fortune.
Wou'd she had less of both, and more of pity.
And that I knew not how to wish, till now
That I became a Lover, perhaps as unsuccessful.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I knew my Beauty had a thousand Darts,
But knew not they cou'd strike so quick and home.
Let your good wishes for your Friend alone,
Lest he being happy, you shou'd be undone,
For he and you, cannot be blest at once.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: How Madam?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I am that Maid he loves, and who hates him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Hate him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: To death.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Oh me unhappy.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He sighs, and turns away—am I again defeated?
Surely I am not fair, or Man's insensible.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: She knows me not—
And 'twas discreetly done to change my shape;
For Woman, is a strange Fantastick Creature,
And where before, I cou'd not gain a smile,
Thus I may win her heart.
—Say Madam, can you love a Man that dies for you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The way to gain me, is to fight with Bellmour.
Tell him from me you come, the wrong'd Diana,
Tell him, y'ave an interest in my heart
Equal to that which I have made in yours.

sp.speaker: Friend▪
sp.l: I'll do't; I will not ask your Reason, but obey.
Swear e're I go, that when I have perform'd it,
You'll render me possession of your heart.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: By all the Vows that Heaven tyes hearts together with,
I'll be entirely yours.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: And I'll not be that conscientious Fool
To stop at blessings 'cause they are not lawful,
But take 'em up, when Heaven has thrown 'em down,
Without the leave of a Religious Ceremony.
Madam, this House, which I am Master of,
You shall command, whil'st I go seek this Bellmour.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But e're you go, I must inform you why
I do pursue him with my just Revenge.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: I will attend, and hear impatiently.

div.head: Scene a Bawdy-house.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Driver, and Betty Flauntit.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Driver, prethee call for a Glass, that I may set my self in order, before I go up, for really my Knight has not been at home all this night, and I am so confus'd—
sp.stage: Enter one with a Glass, and two Wenches.
sp.p:
Lord Mrs. Driver, I wonder you shou'd send for me when other Wome •
are in company; you know, of all things in the World, I hate Whores, they are the pratingst lewdest poor Creatures in nature; and I wou'd not for any thing, Sir Timothy shou'd know that I keep company, 'twere enough to lose him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Driv.
sp.p: Truly Mrs. Flauntit, this young Squire that you were sent to for, has two or three persons more with him that must be accommodated too.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Driver, tho' I do recreate my self a little sometimes, yet you know I value my Reputation and Honour.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Mrs. Driver, why shou'd you send for us where Flauntit is? stinking proud Flirt, who, because she has a tawdrey Petticoat, I warrant you, will think her self so much above us, when if she were set out in her own natural colours, and her original garments, wou'd be much below us in beauty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Driv.
sp.p:
Look ye Mrs. Ienny, I know you, and I know Mrs. Flauntit, but 'tis not Beauty or Wit that takes now adayes; the Age is alter'd since I took upon me this Gentile Occupation, but 'tis a fine Petticoat, right Points, and clean Ga • nitures, that does me credit, and takes the Gallant, tho' on a stale Woman: And again, Mrs. Ienney, she's kept, and
Men love as much for Malice, as for Lechery, as they call it. Oh 'tis a great mover to joy, as they say, to have a Woman that's kept.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Well! be it so, we may arrive to that excellent degree of Cracking, to be kept too one day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Driv.
sp.p: Well, well, get your selves in order to go up to the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Driver, what art thou talking to those poor creatures, Lord how they stink of Paint and Pox, faugh—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Driv.
sp.p: They were only complaining that you that were kept, shou'd intrude upon the priviledges of the Commoners.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p:
Lord, they think there are such joyes in keeping, when I vow Driver, after awhile, a Miss has as painful a life, as a Wife, our Me •
• rink, stay out late, and Whore, like any Husbands.

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.p: But I hope in the Lord, Mrs. Flauntit, yours is no such Man, I never saw him, but I have heard he is under decent correction.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p:
Thou art mistaken Driver, I can keep him within no moderat •
bounds without blows; but for his filthy custom of Wenching, I have almost broke him of that—but prethee Driver, who are these Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.p: Truly, I know not, but they are young, and fine as Princes; two of 'em were disguis'd in Masquing Habits last night, but they have sent 'em away this morning, and they're free as Emperors—one of 'em has lost a thousand pounds at Play, and never repin'd at it: one's a Knight, and I believe his courage is cool'd, for he has ferretted my Maids over and over to night—But 'tis the fine, young handsom Squire th • t I design you for.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: No matter for his handsomness, let me have him that has most money.

div.head: Scene a Chamber, a Tabl • with Box and Dice.
div.stage: Enter Bellmour, Sir Timothy, Sham and Sharp.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Damn it, give us more Wine.
Where stands the Box and Dice?—Why Sham.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, your luck's so bad, I han't the conscience to play longer—Sir Timothy and you play off a hundred Guinneys, and see if luck will turn.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you take me for a Countrey Squire, whose Reputation will be crackt at the loss of a petty thousand? you have my Note for't to my Goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: 'Tis sufficient if it were for ten thousand▪

sp.speaker: Bell▪
sp.p:
Why Sir Timothy—Pox on't thou'rt dull, we are not half d •
baucht and lewd enough, give us more Wine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Faith Franck, I'm a little maukish with sitting up all night, and want a small refreshment this morning—Did we not send for Whores?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: No, I am not in humor for a Wench—
By Heaven I hate the Sex.
All but divine Celinda▪
Appear strange Monsters to my eyes and thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: What art Italianiz'd, and lovest thy own Sex?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm for any thing that's out of the common Road of Sin, I love a Man that will be damn'd for something! To creep by slow degrees to Hell, as if he were afraid the World shou'd see which way he went, I scorn it, 'tis like a Conventickler—No, give me a Man, who, to be certain of's damnation, will break a Solemn Vow to a Contracted Maid.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I thought thou wou'dst have said at least—had murder'd his Father, or ravish • d his Mother—break a Vow quoth ye—by Fortune I have broke a thousand.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well said my Boy! a Man of Honour! and will be ready when e're the Devil calls for thee—So—ho—more Wine, more Wine, and Dice.
sp.stage: Enter a Servant with Dice and Wine.
sp.l: Come, Sir, let me—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim,
sp.l: What will you set me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Cater Tray—a hundred Guinneys—oh damn the Dice— 'tis mine—come a full Glass—Damnation to my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: By Fortune, I'll do thee reason—give me the Glass—and Sham, to thee—Confusion to the musty Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: So—now I'm like my self, profanely wicked.
A little room for life—but such a life
As Hell it self shall wonder at—I'll have a care
To do no one good deed in the whole course on't,
Lest that shou'd save my Soul in spite of Vow-breach.
—I will not dye—that peace my sins deserve not.
I'll live, and let my Tyrant Uncle, see
The sad effects of Perjury, and forc'd Marriage.
—Surely the Powers above envy'd my bliss,
Marrying Celinda, I had been an Angel!
So truly blest, and good.

sp.speaker: Sir Tsm.
sp.p: Why how now Franck—by Fortune the Rogue is Maudlin —So, ho, ho, so-ho.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Oh art awake—What a Devil ayl'st thou Franck?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A Wench, or any thing—come, let • s drink a roun • ,

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.l: They're come as wisht for.

div.stage: Enter Flauntit, Driver, Doll and Jenny mask'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh Damn 'em! What shall I do?
Yet it wou'd look like Virtue to avoid 'em.
No, I must venture on—Ladies y'are welcom.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How the Women?—Hold, hold, Bellmour, let me choose too—Come, come, unmask, and shew your pretty Faces.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: How? Sir Timothy! What Devil ow'd me a spite.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Come, unmask, I say, a willing Wench wou'd have shew'd all in half this time.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: Wou • d she so Imp • dence!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: How! my Betty!

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: This is the Trade you drive, you eternal Fopp, when I sit at home expecting you night after night.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Nay dear Betty!—

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: 'Tis here you spend that which should buy me Points, and Petticoats, whil'st I go like no bodies Mistriss, I'd as live be your Wife at this rate, so I had; and I'm in no small danger of getting the Foul Disease by your Lewdness.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Victorious Betty, be merciful, and do not ruine my Reputation amongst my Friends.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: Your Whores, you mean, you Sott you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Nay triumphant Betty, hear thy poor Timy.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: My poor Ninny, I'm us'd barbarously, and won't endure it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I've won Money to night, Betty, to buy thee Cloaths—hum —hum—Well said Franck, towse the little Jilts, they came for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: The Devil confound him, what a Prize have I lost by his being here—my comfort is, he has not found me out tho', but thinks I came to look for him, and accordingly I must dissemble.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What's here? a Lady all in tears!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: An old acquaintance of mine, that takes it unkindly that I am for change—Betty, say so too, you know I can settle nothing till I'm Married, and he can do it swingingly, if we can but draw him in.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: This mollifies something, do this, and you'll make your peace; if not, you Rascal your Ears shall pay for this nights transgression.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Come hither Franck, is not this a fine Creature!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: By Heaven a very Devil!—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Come, come, approach her, for if you'll have a Miss, this has all the good qualities of one—go, go—Court her, thou art so bashful—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
I cannot frame my tongue to so much blasphemy, as 'tis to say kind things to her—I'll try my heart tho'—Fair Lady—Damn her, she
is not fair—nor sweet—nor good—nor—something I must say for a beginning. Come Lady—dry your eyes.
sp.l: This Man deserves not all the tears you shed.
—So—at last the Devil has got the better of me,
And I am enter'd.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: You see, Sir, how miserable we Women are that love you
Men.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: How did you love him! love him against his will.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: So it seems, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh thou art wretched then indeed; no wonder if he hate thee—
Does he not Curse thee? Curse thee till thou'rt damn'd, as I do lost Diana?

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: Curse me! he were not best in my hearing,
Let him do what he will behind my back.
What ails the Gentleman?—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Gods! What an odious thing meer Coupling is!
A thing which every sensual Animal
Can do as well as we—but prethee tell me,
Is there nought else between the Nobler Creatures?

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Not that I know of, Sir—Lord he's very silly, or very innocent, I hope he has his Maidenhead; if so, and rich too, oh what a booty were this for me!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous strange,
Why was not I, created like the rest;
Wild, and insensible, to fancy all.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you must learn to be gay, to sing, to dance, and talk of any thing, and fancy any thing that's in your way too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh I can towse, and ruffle, like any Leviathan when I begin—
Come prove my vigor.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: Oh Lord Sir! you tumble all my garniture.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: There's Gold to buy thee more—

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Oh sweet Sir—wou'd my Knight were hang'd, so I were well rid of him now—Well Sir, I swear you are the most agreeable person —

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Am I?—let us be more familiar then—I'll kiss thy hand; thy breast, thy lips—and—

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: All—you please Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A tractable Sinner!
Faugh—how she smells—had I approach'd so near divine Celinda, what a natural Fragrancy had sent it self through all my ravisht senses!

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: The Man's extasi'd, sure I shall take him.
Come, Sir, you'are sad.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: As Angels fall'n from the Divine abode,
And now am lighted on a very Hell!
—But this is not the way to thrive in wickedness▪
I must rush on to ruine—Come fair Mistress,
Will you not shew me some of your Arts of Love,
For I am very apt to learn of Beauty—Gods—
What is it I negotiate for—a Woman!
Making a bargain to possess a Woman!
Oh never, never!

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: The Man is in Love, that's certain—as I was saying,
Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Be gone Repentance! thou needless goodness,
Which if I follow, canst lead me to no joyes.
Come tell me the price of all your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Look you Mistriss, I am but a Countrey Knight,
Yet I shou'd be glad of your farther acquaintance.
—Pray who may that Lady be—

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.l: Who Mrs. Flauntit Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim
sp.l: I she? she's tearing fine by Fortune.

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.p: I'll assure you, Sir, she's kept—and is a great Rarity, but to a Friend or so—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Hum—kept—pray by whom?

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.l: Why a silly Knight Sir, that—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I, I, silly indeed—a Pox upon her—a silly Knight you say—

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.l: Ay, Sir, one she makes a very Ass of.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim▪
sp.p: Ay so methinks—but she's kind, and will do reason for all him.

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.l: To a Friend, a Man of Quality—or so.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Ay s • e blinds the Knight.

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, easily—he, poor Cully, thinks her a very Saint— but when he's out of the way, she comes to me to pleasure a Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: But what if the Fool miss her?

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.p: She cryes Whore first, brings him upon his Knees for her fault, and a piece of Plate, or a new Petticoat, makes his Peace again.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why—look you Mistriss, I am that Fopp, that very silly Knight, and the rest that you speak of.

sp.speaker: Driv.
sp.p: How Sir? then I m • undone, she's the upholder of my Calling, the very grace of my Function.

sp.speaker: S • r Tim.
sp.p: Is she so? ee'n keep her to your self then, I • ll have no more of her, by Fortune—I humbly thank you for your intelligence, and the rest. Well—I see there's not one honest Whore i'th' Nation, by Fortune.
sp.l: Heark ye Mistriss, what was your bus'ness here?

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: To meet a R • gue!—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: And I to meet a Whore, and now wee're well met.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Nay never be surpriz'd, for your Intrigues are discover'd, the good Matron of the House (against her Will) has done me that kindness —you know how to live without your Keeper, and so I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: You're too serviceable a Fool to be lost so.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who knows this bold Intruder?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How, Sir, am I a stranger to you! but I shou'd not wonder at it, since all your last Nights actions betray'd a strange depravity of Sense. —Sir, I have sought you long, and wish I had not found you yet, since both the place and company declare, how grosly you've dissembled Virtue all this while.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Take hence that prating Boy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How Sir?—You are my elder Brother, yet I may be allow'd to do the bus'ness that I came for, and from my Uncle to demand your Wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You may return, and tell him that she's dead.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Dead! sure, Sir, you Rave.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Indeed I do—but yet she's dead they say.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: How came she dead?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I kill'd her—ask no more but leave me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Sir, this is Madmans language, and not to be believ'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Go to—y'are a sawcy Boy.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Sir, I'm an angry Boy—
But yet can bear much from a Brothers mouth,
Y'ave lost your sleep, pray Sir, go home and seek it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Home! I have no home, unless thou meanst my Grave,
And thither I cou'd wish, thou wou'dst conduct me.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.l: Pray Heaven this young virtuous Fellow don't spoil all.
—Sir, shall I send for a Scrivener to draw the Settlement you promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Do so, and I'll order him to get it ready.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: A Settlement! on whom? this Woman Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes, on this Woman Sir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Are you stark mad?—Know you where you are?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes, in a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And this Woman, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A very Whore!—a tawdrey mercenary Whore!
And what of this?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: And can you love her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: No, if I did, I wou'd not gratifie her.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What—is't in Charity to keep her honest?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Is your Lust grown so high—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Take that—
For naming but so base a thing to me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I wear a Sword, but not to draw on mad Men.
sp.p: But since y'are so free Sir, I demand that Fortune, which by my Fathers Will, y'are bound to pay the day after your Wedding day; my Sister's too is due.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—Sir Timothy, come hither—who dost think this is?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A Fidler perhaps—let him play in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, my Brother—come to demand his Portion of me—he says I am in lewd company, and, like a Boy, he wou'd correct me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Why this comes of idleness, thou shouldst have bound him Prentice in time, the Boy wou'd have made a good sawcy Taylor.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sirra, y'are a Rascal, whom I must thus chastise.

div.stage: [They all draw, and Bellmour stands foremost, and fights with Charles, the Women run squeaking out, Sir Tim. Sham and Sharp sneak behind, Trusty interposes.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I beseech you my dear Masters! oh what a sight is this! two Brothers fighting with each other! oh, were my old Master alive, this wou'd break his heart: oh, Sir, you've kill'd your Brother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why then his Portion's paid.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How kill • d? nay 'tis time we departed then, and shifted for our selves.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Oh Sir, shall I send for a Chyrurgion.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No for a Coach rather, I am not wounded much.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How dar'st thou trust thy self alone with me?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Why shou'd I fear thee?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Because I'm mad.
Mad as a Tygress rob'd of her dear young.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What is't that makes you so?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My Uncles Politicks, Hell take him for't,
Has ruin'd me, thou and my sister too.
By Marrying me to a fair hated Maid,
When I had plighted all my Faith before.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.l: Sir, here's a Coach.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Come, Brother, will you go home with me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Home!—no, never to that place thou call'st so,
If when I'm dead, thou would'st behold thy Brother,
And take the last adieu from his cold lips:
(If those so Perjur'd can deserve that kindness;)
Inquire for lost Celinda, at who • e feet
Thou shalt behold me fall'n a Sacrifice.
Till then, I'll let mistaken Parents know
The mischiefs that ensue a broken Vow.

div.head: Scene Covent-garden.
div.p: SUre I rose the wrong way to day, I have had such damn'd ill luck every way: First to be • ent for to such a Man as this Bellmour, and, as the Devil wou'd have it, to find my Knight there: Then to be just upon the point of making my Fortune, and to be interrupted by that virtuous Brother of his: Then to have a quarrel happen, that (before I could whisper him in the ear, to say so much as meet me here again—anon) forc'd me to quit the house, lest the Constable had done it for me: Then that that silly Bawd shou'd discover all to my Cully; if this be not ill luck, the Devil • s in't—But Driver must bring matters about, that I may see this liberal Squire again—But here comes my Noddy, I must pretend to be angry.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, how you look now, as if you had committed no misdemeanor; alas, good Innocent, what canst thou say for thy self, thou Renegado thou, for being false to my bosom, say?

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: False to your bosom! You silly impudent Sott you—who dares accuse me?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: E'en your trusty and well-beloved Friend Mrs. Driver the Bawd.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: She! she's an impudent confounded Lyar—and because she wou'd have your Worshipful Custom—scandaliz'd me, to breed a difference between us.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I, if you cou'd make me believe that indeed, when she knew me not, nor ever saw me all dayes of her life before.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: I know that Simpleton, but when I went to inquire for you by your name, and told her my bus'ness, our Amours are not kept so secret, nor was she so dull, as not to understand how matters went between us.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Now, tho • I know this to be a damn'd Lye, yet the Devil has assisted her to make it look so like Truth, that I cannot in Honour but forgive her.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p:
Forgive me!—Who shall forgive you your debauch'd Whoring and Drinking—marry y'had need so you are such a Ruffler, at
least if y'are everywhere as you are at home with me—No, Sirra, I'll never Bed with you more; here I live sneaking without a Coach, or any thing to appear withall; when even those that were scandalous two Ages ago, can be seen in Hide-Park in their fine Chariots, as if they had purchas'd it with a Maidenhead; whil'st I, who k •• p my self entirely for you, can get nothing but the Fragments of your Debauches—I'll be damn'd before I'll endure it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Just as the Bawd said, yet I am mollifi'd—nay, dear Betty forgive me, and I'll be very good for the future.

sp.speaker: Flaunt
sp.p: Will you swear to be so?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I, by Fortune I will.

sp.speaker: Flaunt
sp.p: Come, what will you give me then to be Friends? for you won Money last Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, that • s it that appeases her highest storms—here my Jewel, here's a hundred Guineys to buy thee fine things.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Yes, great store of fine things, indeed, with this pitifu • Sum, let me feel in your Pockets, and see if you have no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: So, 'twas well I laid by the rest, my Peace had not been made under every Rag on't else; and what I was painfully cheating for all this Night, would have been laid out at the Mercers and Lacemans in half an hour—Well, are you satisfi'd I have no more?

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Have you sunk none indeed, and indeed, my Timmy?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: No, I need not, you sink mine fast enough, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Well, get your self ready to go abroad with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I have other matters in hand—now have I Four hundred Guineys in Bank, which I won last Night of Bellmour, which I'll make use of to debauch his sister, with whom I'm damnably in love, and long for the return of my two Setting Dogs, to bring me News of the Game.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, with News worth the hearing; I have been diligent, Sir, and got my self acquainted with the old Steward of the Family, an avaricious Iudas, that will betray for Gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: And that we'll furnish him with—his Masters Gold, like all other mortal things, must return from whence it came.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Not all, Sir, for Sham and I have dispos'd of part.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Indeed you are a little shabby.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, Fools were made to repair the breaches of us that have Wit enough to manage 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What—the Goldsmith paid the Money at sight, without demanding why?

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Readily Sir—he's a brave Fellow, and must not be lost so.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: By no means, we must make use of him whil'st he's hot, for I doubt the humor is not natural, and I fear he may cool.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: But to our bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, this same Sister of his you must have.
If it be but to put that insolent Whore Flauntit out of favour, who manages this Fopp too intirely.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Ay, but art thou sure there is no danger in this Enterprize? shall I not have my throat cut? and the rest.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: We have none of that Italian humor now adayes, I can assure ye; they will sooner with a Brotherly kindness, assist the yielding Sister, to the willing Gallant.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A good thriving inclination, by Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: And, Sir, you have all encouragement; her Brother, you heard, refus'd to pay her Portion, and you know the Fate of a young handsom Wench in this Town, that relies on weak Virtue—then because she's in the house with her Uncle, this same Steward has contriv'd matters so, to bring you in at the Back-door, her Lodgings being in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: This is something—oh I'm impatient to be with her— Well, I must in, and make some Lye to Betty for my absence, and be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What design hast thou in hand? for I suppose there is no such real thing, as the debauching of this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Look ye Sharp, take to thee an implicit Faith, and believe impossibilities; for thou and I must cozen this Knight.

sp.speaker: Sharp.
sp.p: What our Patron?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I Sharp, we are bound to labour in our Callings, but mum— here he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Come, let's away, my Lyoness begins to roar.
—You Sharp go seek after Bellmour, watch his motions, and give us notice.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p:
He is gone, and I believe
[Betty Flauntit peeping out. For no goodness; I'll after him, and watch him.

div.stage: Enter Lord Plotwell, Charles, Trusty, and two Servants.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
In a Bawdy-house, with Whores, Hectors, and Dice! oh that I shou'd be so deceiv'd in Mankind, he whom I thought all Virtue and
Sobriety! but go some of you immediately, and take Officers along with you, and remove his Quarters, from a Bawdy-house to a Prison, charge him with the murder of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My Lord, when I demanded her, he said indeed that she was dead, and kill'd by him; but this, I guess, was the effects of madness, which debauchery, and want of sleep, has brought him to.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That shall be try'd; go to the place where Charles has directed you, and do as I command you.
sp.l: —Oh sweet Diana. in whom I had plac'd my absolute delight,
And gave thee to this Villain, because I wisht thee happy.
And are my expectations fall'n to this?
Upon his Wedding Night to abandon thee!
And shew his long dissembled Natural Lewdness.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My Lord, I hope, 'tis not his Natural Temper,
For e're we parted, from a Brutal Rudness,
He grew to all the softness Grief cou'd dictate.
He talkt of breach of Vows, of Death, and Ruine,
And dying at the feet of a wrong'd Maid,
I know not what he meant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ay, there's his grief; there is some Jilting Hussy has drawn him in, but I'll revenge my self on both.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: A Letter for your Lordship.

body.p: AS your goodness has been ever great towards me, so I humbly beseech • ou to continue it; and the greatest proofs you can give me of it, is to use all your int'rest to undo that tye between Bellmour and my self, which with such joy you knit. I will say no more, but as you love my Life, and my dearer Honour, get a Divorce, or you will see both Ruin'd in

sp.p: A Divorce; yes, if all my Interest or Estate can purchase it—some joy yet that thou art well.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Doubtless her Reasons must be great for this Request.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes, for she lov'd him passionately, when I first told her of my desi • ns to Marry 'em together, she could not hide her joy; which was one Motive, I urg'd it to him with such violence.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Persons so near of Kin, do seldom prosper in the Marriage Bed.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: However 'tis, I now think fit to unmarry 'em;
And as for him, I'll use him with what Rigor,
The utmost limits of the Law allows me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You beseech me! you, the Brother of the Villain! That has abus'd the best of all my hopes?—no I think—I shall grow (for his sake) to hate all that belong to him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sir, how have I offended?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes Sir, you have offended me, and Nature has offended me; you are his Brother, and that's an offence to me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Is that a fault, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, a great one, and I'll have it so; and let me tell you, you nor your Sister (for that Reason) must expect no more friendship at my hands, than from those that are absolute strangers to you: your Brother has refus'd you your Portions, and I'll have as little mercy as he, and so farewell to you—But where's the Messenger that brought the Letter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Without my Lord.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Here's like to be a hopeful end of a Noble Family. My comfort is, I shall dye with grief, and not see the last of ye.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No Trusty, I have not been so meanly educated, but I know how to live, and like a Gentleman: all that afflicts me in this misfortune, is my dear Sister Phillis; she's young, and to be left poor in this loose Town, will ruine her for ever.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Sir I think we were best to Marry her out of the way.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Marry her! to whom? who is't regards poor Virtue?

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: For that let me alone; and if you dare trust her to my management, I'll undertake to Marry her to a Man of 2000 l. a year; and if I fail, I'll be sure to keep her Honour safe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Prethee how wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Sir, I have serv'd your Family these thirty years, with faith and love, and if I lose my credit now, I'll ne'r pretend to't more.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt, for I am sure thou'rt honest,
And I'll resign my Sister to thy conduct,
Whil'st I endeavor the conversion of my Brother.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: No News yet of my Brother.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: None: the next you'll hear is, that he's undone, and that you must go without your Portions; and worse than that, I can tell you your Uncle designs to turn you out of doors.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p:
Alas! what shou'd I do, if he shou'd be so cruel? Wou'd I
were in Flanders at my Monastry again, if this be true.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: I have better bus'ness for you, than telling of Beads— No, Mrs. Phillis you must be Married.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Alas! I am too young, and sad for Love.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: The younger, and the less Love, the better.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Mr. Trusty, here's a Gentleman wou'd speak with you, he says his name • s Mr. Sham.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Gud's me Mistriss, put on all your Holyday looks, for this is the little Merchant of Love by Retail, that brings you the Husband I promis'd you.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Well Mr. Trusty, I have brought Sir Timothy, as I promis'd, he is at the Garden door.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: The best time in the World, my Lord's out of the way.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: But you know our conditions.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Yes, that if he Marry her, you are to have all the Money that he offers to debauch her.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Bring him in then, and I'll civilly withdraw.

div.stage: Enter Sham, bringing in Sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Well Sham, thou hast prepar'd all things, and there needs no Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: None, none Sir, you may fall down-right to the bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.l: Come, my Phillis, let us improve
Both our joyes of equal Love,
Whil'st we in yonder shady Grove,
Count Minutes by our Kisses.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: What sort of Courtship's this? 'tis very odd!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: 'Pox on Formal Fopps, we have high-born and generous Souls, and scorn the common Road—Come, let's enjoy, whil'st Youth and Beauty lasts.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: What means this Rudeness? I'll tell my Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Your Brother, by Fortune he's so lewd, that should I be so unconscionable to leave thee a Virgin but this Night, he would Ravish thee himself, and that at cheaper Rates than I design to do it.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: How dare you talk to me at this rate?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Talk to thee—by Fortune I'll play the Tarquin with thee, if thou yieldst not quickly—for thou hast set me all on fire.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Defend me, Heav'n from such a Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Then it must defend you from all the Sex, for all Mankind are like me, nay, and all Woman-kind are, or wou'd be, what I must make thee

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: What's that, a Wench?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Fie, fie, that's a gross name, no, a Miss, that's the word— a Lady of delight, a Person of pleasure, and the rest; I'll keep thee, not a Woman of Quality shall be half so fine—Come, dear Phillis, yield▪ Oh I am mad for the happy hour—come, say the word, 'tis but incl •• ning thy head a little thus—the pretty Eyes down, and thy Cheeks all blushes, and fetching a long sigh—thus—with—do—what you please—at the end on't—and I shall take it for granted.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: That, Sir, you'll never hear me say to any thing but a Husband, if I must say it then.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: A Husband! it is enough to spoil a Mans appetite, the very naming on't—By Fortune thou hast been bred with thy great Grandmother, some old Queen Elizabeth Lady, that us'd to preach warnings to young Maidens; but had she liv'd in this Age, she wou'd have repented her Error, especially had she seen the Sum that I offer thee— Come, let's in, by Fortune, I'm so vigorous, I shall ravish else.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Unhand me, or I'll call out. I assure you this is not the way to gain me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I know there is a way to gain all mortal Woman-kind, but how to hit the Critical Minute of the Berjere—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Is past your Politicks at this time Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I'll try all wayes, and the Devil's in't if I don't hit upon the right at last.
All the soft things I've said—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: That a • night of your Parts ought to say.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Then I have kneel'd—and cry d—and swore—and—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: And damn'd your self five hundred times—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Yet still y'are impregnable—I • ll make another Proposition to you, which is both reasonable and modish—If it prove a Boy— I'll Marry you—the Devil's in't, if that be not fair.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: You get no earnest of me, Sir, and so farewell to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p:
Oh Sham, I am all over fire, mad to enjoy! I have done what Man can do (without doing what I wou'd do) and still she's Flint; nothing will down with her but Matrimony—what shall I do? for thou
knowst I cannot Marry a Wife without a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Sir, you know the old Cheat, hire a Lay Rascal in a Canonical Habit, and put a false Marriage upon her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Lord, that this shou'd not enter into my Coxcomb before? haste then and get one—I'll have it done immediately, whilst I go after her to keep up my flame.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: And I'll fit you with a Parson presently.

div.head: The Scene a Street.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
I find Diana knows me not, and this years absence, since I fir ••
made my Addresses to her, has alter'd me much, or she has lost the remembrance of a Man, whom she ever disesteem'd till in this lucky dress, the price of her Favour is Bellmour's life; I need not have been brib'd for that, his breach of Faith both to my sister and my self, enough incites me to Revenge—He has not yet enjoy'd her, that blessing is reserv'd for me alone; and tho' the Priest have join'd 'em, that Marriage may be disannull'd, and she has a Fortune sufficient to excuse her other faults.
sp.l: —Hah! the Man I seek—so near my Lodgings too—Sir!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Traytor! thou knowst me, and my bus'ness.
sp.p: —Look on this face, if thou dar'st look on him, whom thou hast doubly wrong'd—and draw thy Sword.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thou shou'dst be Friendlove, Brother to Celinda.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: And Lover of Diana too—oh quickly draw,
Or I shall leave thee like a Coward, dead.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: No, rather like a Sacrifice,
And thou shou'dst be the Priest should offer it;
But that I have yet
For some few moments, bus'ness for my life.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: I can allow no time for bus'ness now,
My injuries are in haste, and so am I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Should'st thou stab here, a thousand gaping wounds,
Upon this false, this perjur'd heart of mine,
It wou'd not part with life, unless 'twere laid
Near to the Sacred Altar of my Vows.
Lo at the feet of my fair injur'd Wife.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Ha!—means • e his Wife!
Canst thou repent thy injuries to her,
And leave the rest of all thy sins neglected?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Those I have done to thee, tho' soul and barb'rous
May plead the excuse of force—but those to her,
Not thou, nor I, nor she, or Heav'n can pardon.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Heav'ns!
My sisters wrongs, and mine, may plead excuse,
But those to her alone can ne're be pardon'd.
—This place, Sir, is too open—come with me,
For I've desir'd, and now resolve to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And so thou shalt, defenceless, I will yield,
And leave my bosom, open to thy Sword.
—But first conduct me to my Wife.
For I will see her—nor can I dye unpardon'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: See his Wife!—of whom do you demand her?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Of thee!—dar'st thou detain me?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Death how shou'd he know she's here!
—Stay, Sir, this way our bus'ness lies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I ask not thine, but mine lies only this way.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: By Heav'n you shall not enter here!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I know thou lovest her,
And 'tis with reason thou deny'st an entrance
To one so much unworthy to approach her.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Yes, I do love her, and dare own it too;
And will defend her from one so base and treacherous.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Who dares • eny thy Reasons?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Sh'as made me take an Oath, to fight with thee.
And every wound, my lucky Sword shou'd make,
She bad me say, was sent thee from her hate.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh I believe thee! prethee tell on, young man,
That I may dye without the aid of wounds.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: To break thy heart, know then, she loves another.
And has took back the Vows she made to thee,
And given 'em to a Man more worthy of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Alas! I credit thee—yet—then by Heav'n she's false!
And I will know, why 'tis she is thus perjur'd.
—Nay now—nor Heav'n, nor Hell, shall hinder me.
—Stand off, or to the number I'll add one sin more,
And make my passage to her through thy heart.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: And so you shall Sir.
sp.stage: [They fight, Bellmour disarms Friend. and runs in.
sp.l: —Disarm'd! by Heav'n you shall not so escape
A Rage that is too just here to give o're.

div.stage: The Scene changes to the inside of Friendloves Lodgings.
Enter Celinda, as before, met by Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Oh Madam, here's Mr. Bellmour, he has wounded my young Master, who deni'd him entrance, and is come into the house, and all in Rage demands his Wife.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh Heav'n! demands his Wife! is that sad Curse
Added to all the rest—does he then love her?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Whether do you press Sir? And what's your business?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: To see my Wife, my Wife, impertinence.
And must I meet with nought but opposition?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Let him come in.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry he lets himself in, I thank him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What Man art thou thus cover'd o're with horror!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: One sent from Hell, to punish Perjury!
—Where's this perfidious Fair? this blushless Maid!
That has by my example broke her Vows!
A President that Fiends, wou'd shame to follow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Who is't you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A thing that has no name, she is so bad!
One who so lately gave her self to me,
And now is flown into anothers Arms.
One that attacks my life, for the same sins,
Which she her self commits—and thinks to live too.
—Yet still she is my Wife, whom I have injur'd:
Till when, she was a Saint—come lead me to her.
Tho' she be false as I, yet I'll forgive it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Heav'ns! he repents his Cruelty to her,
And never mentions me! Ah then 'tis time to die.
And that I may be sure of death—
Well, Sir, I will conduct this happy Lady to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Gods! happy!—whil'st I am wretched.
—Oh what an Ague chills my shivering Limbs,
Turns my hot rage, to softest love, and shame,
Were I not here to dye—here at her feet,
I wou'd not stand the shock of her Reproaches.
—But yet she need not speak, a look's sufficient
To call up all my sins to my undoing—
—She comes—Oh Heav'n! she comes—
—Like penitent Criminals thus—with my Eyes declin'd,
I bow my head down, for the last sad blow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, in obedience to your Commands,
I've brought the Lady.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: How! the perfidious Bellmour!
The only object of my hate and scorn.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Say on, my angry Deity—
Whil'st I thus trembling hear my fatal doom
Like sinners conscious, ne're to be forgiven,
I dare not lift my guilty Eyes towards Heaven.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Can I hear this? and yet retain my life!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Had I but two days since beheld this Youth
Thus prostrate at my feet, I shou'd have thought
My self more blest,
Than to have been the Deity he calls me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Defend me! the Traytor here! and at Diana's feet,
The fittest Altar for my Sacrifice!
—Turn, turn, from what thou lovest, and meet my justice!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh hold, my dearest Brother!

sp.speaker: Bellm.
sp.l: Nay, now I'm ready for the welcom Sword,
Since my Celinda's false, and cannot pardon.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh do not dye with that prophane opinion.
Celinda fal • e! or cannot pardon thee!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Stay, generous Sir, my pity has forgiven him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thou! why who art thou—Diana!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yes, that Diana
Whom maugre all the Penitence thou shew'st,
Can scarce forgive the injuries thou'st done her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I shew a Penitence for injuring thee!
By Heav'n I never cou'd do one, or other,
All that I am is the divine Celinda's.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: He's stark mad Î

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But since she cannot pardon, I can dye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Canst thou not credit me! she pardons thee.
Live—and enjoy—Diana.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What art thou? who knowst her heart so well!
Art thou my Rival? the blessed Youth to whom
She has given her Vows?—live—and enjoy—Diana!
—Yes—yes—thou art my Rival, and I'll kill thee.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Do, whilst I meet thy Sword.

div.stage: [Opens her Arms, Dia. stays him, he lets fall his Sword, and gazes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Dull—dull Adorer! not to know my Saint.
Oh how have I prophan'd? to what strange Idol
Was that I kneel'd?
Mistaking it for a Divinity!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To your fair Wife Diana!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh cruel Maid!
Has Heav'n design'd me any but Celinda!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Maid! bless me!—did I then love a Woman!
—I am pleas'd thou shou'dst renounce me, make it good,
And set me free from Fetters which I hate.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If all our Laws can do't I will—for here
Ends all my claim.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Was this the Wife you did demand of me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes, I had no other.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Fair Maid! forgive me all my shameful Passion!
And charge my fault upon your Beauty only.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Excellent Creature! I shou'd sue for that
Which my deceit will never make me hope.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And art thou true to Love, and all thy Vows?
Whilst I to save my Fortune,
(That only which cou'd make me merit thee)
Gave my unwilling hand to this fair Noble Maid.
—Ah Friendlove, when thou hearst my Story told,
Thou wilt forgive, and pity me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What was't you said Sir?—Friendlove.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, I hope the name can make no diff'rence:
Or hate that still, so you love the Man.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Tho' I'm again defeated, yet this last
Proves least offensive, nor shall an empty word,
Alter my fix'd Resolves, to love you still.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Then I am blest!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But yet the office of the Priest has past.
What remedy for that?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My Uncle's pow'r; the nearness of our blood,
The contradiction of our circumstances.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And above all that, my Contract with Celinda.
—Methinks I feel a joy spread o're my heart,
The blessed omen of approaching happiness.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I do believe thee, for by sympathy,
Mine takes new fire and hope.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I have already writ to my Uncle, and the Messenger assur'd me,
he would gratifie my desires; that done, I will be yours.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But why thus drest? it might have led my Rage
Full of despair, and jealousie to have hurt thee,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, when the Letter came of your being Married,
I will not tell you all the effects it had
Upon my desperate Soul;
But this I know, I had resolv'd to dye.
But first to see you, your Page inform'd the Nurse,
All that had past, and of the last Nights Ball;
And much concern'd, she got this Habit for me,
And inform'd me how 'twas I was to Act.
And that my Brother (describing of his dress) was gone before;
This made me haste, lest e're I came,
His Rage had done the bus'ness which it went for.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: And so it had, hadst thou not hinder'd me,
For I, Sir, was the Man, who drew on you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And was it thou that didst defend my heart,
That I might live to pay thy goodness back.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It was to save your life, and to expose my own.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Come, let's in, and consult what's best for us to do.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Come my Celinda,
Let us no longer doubt, the Pow'rs above
Will be propitious to United Love.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, my Lord Plotwell is at the door in his Coach.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My Uncle come! Sir, we will not doubt our Fortune.
But how came he to know of my being here?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Madam, I fear he follow'd me, after I had given him the Letter.
—Rise, the joy I have to see you thus, makes me
Resolve to grant you any thing, and pardon all that's past.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Be not so hasty in your goodness, Sir,
Lest you repent as fast.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Sir, we have an humble Suit to you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: What is it ye can jointly ask, I will not grant?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: By all th • t Love you ever had for me,
By all those Infant charms, which us'd to please you
When on your Lap, you taught my Tongue that Art
Which made those dear impress • ons on your Heart▪
Which ever since to my advantage grew,
I do conjure you hear me now I sue,
And grant the mighty grace I beg of you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: What is it you wou'd ask?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh dress your Face and Eyes in gentler Looks,
If you wou'd have us hope for any mercy.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Rise, and whate're you ask, I'll freely grant.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That you'll undo that knot, that ties us two.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: How! this Request from thee! who lov'd him once,
And wish'd no good beyond possessing him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Heaven has not, Sir, decreed us for each other,
Something of Fate or Chance
Has otherwise dispos'd those first Resolves.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Too virtuous Maid, I know thou dost but feign,
His wickedness has forc'd thee to this change.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: No, Sir, were he the only Man
Of kind and good, I never wou'd be his.
—And if you shou'd compel me, I shou'd live
The infamous Reproach of my whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Well, and you Sir, that are the cause of this,
What canst thou say to move me for thy Pardon?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am so guilty in your opinion,
My Prayers wou'd but make yours merciless;
I only say Celinda is my Wife,
And I shou'd injure this too generous Maid,
Not to adore her equal to her merit.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I see, Sir, you have found your Wits again.
—Well, I see there's no opposing Destiny,
And I have still such tenderness for thee,
That hadst thou pleaded his Cause to me before,
I shou'd have been less cruel to him.
—Where is that Lady which you so admire,
Whose beauty does eclipse that of Diana.

div.stage: Bellmour goes out, and brings in Celinda.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: This, Sir, is she who merits more than I.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: She's fair indeed; here Franck,
I give thee thy Celinda, whose beauty
Excuses all thy faults of disobedience.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thus low, I thank you for this goodness Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: There only wants the ceremony of the Law to undo what's between you and Diana, if she remain a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: For me by Heav'n she is,
And for the rest I do not doubt her virtue.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: You may believe him, Sir▪ and this alone's the Man 〈…〉 I will, or never will be happy.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Mr. Friendlove, I give consent to't, he has a Noble Character, and what he wants in Fortune, has in Virtue—take her young Man.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Tis such an Honour, Sir, that (my Gratitude) without the mighty Passion I have for her, would make me ever thankful.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: This Term, we shall make the former Marriage void, till then love on, and fear no frowns from Fortune—but Nephew—now I hope your Brother shall have his Portion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My dearest Charles, forgive me all that's past, And share the Fortune, Heaven has given thy Brother.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The joy I have, Sir, to be undeceiv'd, is much the greatest blessing Heav'n can send me.

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy follow'd by Phillis, Sham, Sharp, and Betty Flauntit.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: I am pursu'd by two impertinent Women, prethee Friendlove, tell 'em I am gone out at the Back-door, and send 'em away.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What's the News here?

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How Celinda here, and Bellmour too! nay, now wou'd I compound for my Life, at any rate, by Fortune.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Sir, this Villain here has abus'd me, and with a false Marriage has rob'd me of my Honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: My Lord, I say this young Jilt wou'd rob me of my self, and courting her, and enjoying her only for a Miss, would persuade me I am Married to her.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Sir, I say, I am doubly wrong'd; first by this false Knight, who has belong'd to me these three years, which gives me a right to him, as good as if I were Married to him; who has now unlawfully left my Bed, for that of this Gillflurt, who on the other side takes away my Knight, and consequently eats the bread out of my mouth.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What means all this?
Speak some of ye that know.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Oh Lord! who's here? the fine Squire.

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Sir Timothy Tawdrey, Sir, is Married to Mrs. Phillis.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: How can that be a Marriage, when he who join'd us, was but a hired Fellow, drest like a Parson?

sp.speaker: Trust;
sp.p: Sir, 'twas Parson Tickle-text, that Marry'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh what a damn'd lying Pimp is this!—Sham didst not thou hire a Fellow, (because I was damnably in Love, and in haste) to Marry us, that was no Parson?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why truly Sir—I did go to hire such an one—

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Look ye there now.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: But cou'd meet with none; and because you said you shou'd dye if you enjoy'd her not presently, and that she wou'd not yield on any other terms, but those of Marriage, I e'ne brought the Parson that Trusty had provided for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Oh Villain to betray me! and for no Reward!

sp.speaker: Trust.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir, the 400 Guineys you left behind my young Mistresses Looking-glass fell to his share.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: What's my Money gone! and am I Marry'd too! This 'tis not to use to go to Church; for then I might have chanc'd to know the Parson.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Death you Dog! you deserve to dye, for your base designs upon a Maid of her quality—how durst you, Sister, without my leave, Marry that Rascal?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Sir, you deny'd me my Portion, and my Uncle design'd to turn me out of doors▪ and in my despairs, I accepted of him.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: Married! and to a Wife of no Fortune! that's the worst part on't—what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Renounce this lewd Fool, and I'll make thee a Fortune sutable to thy quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Say you so?—Renounce me Sir! I'de have you to know I merit her: and as for Lewdness, I name no body Bellmour—but only some have the Art of hiding it better than I—but for Whoring, Drinking, Dicing, and all the deadly sins that thereupon depend, I thank my stars I come short of you: And since you say, I shall not have your Sister, by Fortune, I will have your Sister, and love your Sister, and lie with your Sister, in spite of you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Well Sir Timothy, since my Neece has done amiss, 'tis too late to mend it—and that you may not repent, I'll take care her Fortune shall be sutable to the Jointure you'll make her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With this Proviso that you make no Settlements to Misses, Sir Timothy—I am not so unreasonable to tye you up from all of that Profession; that were to spoil a fashionable Husband, and so put you quite out of Fopp Road.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: This day we'll set apart for mirth,
And all must make my house their happy home.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: To thee, Celinda, all my good I owe,
My Life, my Fortune, and my Honour too,
Since all had perish'd by a broken Vow.

sp.speaker: Flaunt.
sp.p: What am I like to lose my Timy? Canst thou have the heart to leave me for ever? I who have been true and constrant to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: Alas! now do I melt again, by Fortune—thou art a Fool, dost think I wou'd have had her, but for her Fortune; which shall only serve to make thee out-flaunt all the Cracks in Town—go—go home and expect me, thou'lt have me all to thy self within this day or two.
sp.l: Since Marriage but a larger Licence is
For every Fopp of Mode to keep a Miss.

div.head: Epilogue Spoken by SIR TIMOTHY TAWDREY.
div.l: SIR TIMOTHY, Gallants, at last is come
To know his Sentence, and receive his Doom.
But pray before you are resolv'd to be
Severe, look on your selves, and then on me;
Observe me well, I am a Man of Show,
Of Noise, and Nonsence, as are most of you,
Tho' all of you don't share with me in Title,
In Character you differ very little.
Tell me in what you find a difference?
It may be you will say, you're Men of Sence;
But Faith—
Were one of you o'th' Stage, and I i'th' Pit,
He might be thought the Fopp, and I the Wit.
On equal Grounds you'll scarce know one from t'other;
We are as like, as Brother is to Brother.
To judge against me then wou'd be ill Nature,
For Men are kind to those they're like in Feature.
For Iudges therefore I accept you all;
By you, SIR TIMOTHY will stand or fall.
He's too faint-hearted that his Sentence fears,
Who has the Honour to be try'd by's Peers.

list.head: Playes Printed for I. Magnes and R. Bentley.
list.item: FOrced Marriage: Or the Jealous Bridegroom.
All Mistaken: Or the Mad Couple.
Calisto: Or the Masque at Court, Acted by the Lady Mary and the Lady Anne, and other Persons of the highest quality.
The Town-Fopp: Or Sir Timothy Tawdrey.
Madam Fickle: Or the Witty False One.
